content.question: What is/are the force(s) acting on a symmetrical aerofoil element when the upstream airflow is parallel to the chord line?

options.A: Weight and drag.
options.B: Lift and drag.
options.C: Weight only.
options.D: Zero force because zero lift is generated.

key_points: Symmetrical Aerofoil If a symmetrical airfoil section is in a steady airstream at zero degrees Angle of Attack (airflow is parallel to the chord line), a stagnation point forms on the leading edge
The airflow velocity above and below the airfoil increases by an equal amount and the static pressures reduce by an equal amount
Consequently, no pressure differential exists, and no net lift is created
learning.explanation: Symmetrical Aerofoil If a symmetrical airfoil section is in a steady airstream at zero degrees Angle of Attack (airflow is parallel to the chord line), a stagnation point forms on the leading edge. The airflow velocity above and below the airfoil increases by an equal amount and the static pressures reduce by an equal amount. Consequently, no pressure differential exists, and no net lift is created. Weight and Drag will be acting on the aerofoil. There will be a certain amount of Parasite drag and Weight is due to the the aircraft's mass.

content.question: The lift coefficient CL versus angle of attack curve of a negatively cambered aerofoil section intersects the vertical axis of the graph:

options.A: at the origin.
options.B: below the origin.
options.C: above the origin.
options.D: nowhere.

key_points: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil
For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing
Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord
learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin.

content.question: The coefficient of drag can be defined as the...

options.A: sum of induced drag and parasite drag.
options.B: ratio of lift forces to drag forces.
options.C: measure of the efficiency of the aeroplane.
options.D: ratio of drag pressure to dynamic pressure.

key_points: Dynamic pressure takes into account the air density and velocity, but when combined with the wing planform surface area (S) it produces a force known as drag
Like lift, drag is not exactly equal to the dynamic pressure times the area, but varies with shape and angle of attack
The Coefficient of Drag (CD ) represents these factors
learning.explanation: Dynamic pressure takes into account the air density and velocity, but when combined with the wing planform surface area (S) it produces a force known as drag. Like lift, drag is not exactly equal to the dynamic pressure times the area, but varies with shape and angle of attack. The Coefficient of Drag (CD ) represents these factors. The general drag formula is thus: D= CD * 1 / 2 * ρ * V2 * S Where, D – Drag CD – Drag Coefficient V2 – Airflow Speed squared S – Surface Area ρ – Air density 1 / 2 * ρ * V2 – Dynamic pressure Re-arranging the formula in function of Drag Coefficient: CD = D / (1 /2* ρ* V2*S)

content.question:
Which of these statements about the strength of wing tip vortices are correct or incorrect?
I. Assuming no flow separation, the strength of wing tip vortices increases as the angle of attack increases.
II. The strength of wing tip vortices increases as the aspect ratio increases.

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.C: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift
They are caused by the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing, which causes an updraft of high pressure air around the tip of the wing
This updraft turns into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift. They are caused by the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing, which causes an updraft of high pressure air around the tip of the wing. This updraft turns into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex. The higher the pressure difference between the top and bottom of the wing, the stronger the vortices. This question is specifically asking for: Angle of attack: The strength of the vortices (and therefore also induced drag) is proportional to the angle of attack. Therefore; the strength of the vortices increase as the angle of attack increases, hence statement 1 correct! Aspect ratio: The strength of the vortices is inversely proportional with the aspect ratio. Meaning that the strength of the wing tip vortices decreases as the aspect ratio increases, hence statement 2 is incorrect!

content.question: The point of minimum static pressure on a positively cambered aerofoil flying at a low subsonic speeds at a positive angle of attack is…

options.A: on the upper surface, where the speed is highest.
options.B: on the upper surface, where the speed is lowest.
options.C: on the lower surface, where the dynamic pressure is lowest.
options.D: on the lower surface, where the dynamic pressure is highest.

key_points: Bernoulli’s theorem when applied to the airflow past an aerofoil at less than Mach 0

4 shows that the total pressure is equal to the sum of the dynamic pressure (the pressure caused by the movement of the air) and the static pressure (the pressure of the air not associated with its movement) and can be expressed as the following equation: Total Pressure (pt) = Dynamic Pressure (q) + Static Pressure (ps) The total pressure is constant along a streamline flow
Therefore, if dynamic pressure increases then static pressure decreases and vice versa
learning.explanation: Bernoulli’s theorem when applied to the airflow past an aerofoil at less than Mach 0.4 shows that the total pressure is equal to the sum of the dynamic pressure (the pressure caused by the movement of the air) and the static pressure (the pressure of the air not associated with its movement) and can be expressed as the following equation: Total Pressure (pt) = Dynamic Pressure (q) + Static Pressure (ps) The total pressure is constant along a streamline flow. Therefore, if dynamic pressure increases then static pressure decreases and vice versa. The flow over the top of the section accelerates rapidly around the nose and over the leading portion of the surface - inducing a substantial decrease in static pressure in those areas. The pressure reduces continuously from the stagnation value through the free stream value to a position on the top surface where a peak negative value is reached. From there onwards the flow continuously slows down again and the pressure increases back to the free stream value in the region of the trailing edge.

content.question:
Considering subsonic incompressible airflow through a Venturi, which statement is correct?
1. The static pressure in the throat is lower than in the undisturbed airflow.
2. The speed of the airflow in the throat is lower than in the undisturbed airflow.

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem)
Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time
The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant
learning.explanation: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem). Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time. The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant. The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m= ρ*A*V Continuity equation: m1= m2= m3= ρ1* A1* V1= ρ2* A2* V2= ρ3* A3* V3=constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q= 1/2* ρ* V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. In Conclusion: With a decrease in section area (from station 1 to station 2), flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure. If dynamic pressure increases, static pressure decreases. Statement 1 is therefore correct. With a decrease in section area (from station 1 to station 2), flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure. Statement 2 is therefore incorrect.

content.question: An aeroplane is on final approach at a CAS within the non-stable region of the CAS/drag graph. The aeroplane experiences a change in the wind direction to be less of a headwind with little change in wind speed. This condition will cause...

options.A: a reduction in air speed, which will cause an increase in total drag.
options.B: a reduction in air speed, which will cause a decrease in total drag.
options.C: an increase in air speed, which will cause an increase in total drag.
options.D: an increase in air speed, which will cause a decrease in total drag.

key_points: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight)
The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag
The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag
learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD). Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. Flying at a slower speed than VMD (back side), the aircraft will be in the unstable speed region. Any loss of speed will result in an increase in drag and further speed loss (which must be corrected by an increase in thrust). The sudden change to a tailwind (or a decrease in headwind) will cause a loss of airspeed.

content.question: While performing an obstacle limited take-off, you inadvertently set a lower take-off flap setting (less flap) than the calculated and required. Compared to a take-off at the correct flap setting , the aircraft will pass the departure end of the runway at…

options.A: greater height, as the lower flap setting means that more lift is generated.
options.B: greater height, as the lower flap setting means that a shorter take-off distance is required.
options.C: lower height, as the lower flap setting means that a greater take-off distance is required.
options.D: lower height, as the lower flap setting means that more drag is generated.

key_points: TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial
This permits operation at greater weights from given runway lengths and enables greater payloads to be carried
Returning the flaps to their neutral position when no longer required, returns the wing to its former aerodynamic characteristics
learning.explanation: TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial. This permits operation at greater weights from given runway lengths and enables greater payloads to be carried. Returning the flaps to their neutral position when no longer required, returns the wing to its former aerodynamic characteristics. The increase in lift comes mainly from the variation in effective camber that occurs when the flaps are deflected. This alters the lift curve and also produces a higher maximum coefficient of lift. In some instances, the trailing edge flaps may also increase the wing's surface area. Extending the trailing edge flaps alters the pressure distribution around the wing. USE OF TRAILING EDGE FLAPS FOR TAKE-OFF For take-off purposes, the flaps are normally lowered to a position that provides the best lift-drag ratio that can be obtained with the flaps in any position other than fully up. Since the required lift is obtained at a lower airspeed, the take-off run is also reduced. Larger amounts of flap cause a significant increase in drag, which greatly reduces the acceleration and increases the take-off run. The reduced stalling angle of attack and increased drag associated with flaps also reduces the rate and angle of climb. After take-off, a minimum climb gradient is required in the take-off configuration. Climb gradient is reduced by flap, so if climb gradient is limiting, a lesser flap angle may be selected even though it gives a longer take-off distance.

options.A: CD increases and CL decreases.
options.B: CL decreases but CD remains unaffected.
options.C: CD increases but CL remains unaffected.
options.D: both CL and CD increase.

key_points: SPOILERS Spoilers are flap type control surfaces, normally located on the upper surface of the wing, just in front of the trailing edge flaps
These surfaces individually hinge at their leading edges and are actuated by hydraulic power supplied by dedicated power control units
The main purpose of the surfaces is to disturb the smooth airflow over the top of the wing, thereby reducing the wings lifting capability
learning.explanation: SPOILERS Spoilers are flap type control surfaces, normally located on the upper surface of the wing, just in front of the trailing edge flaps. These surfaces individually hinge at their leading edges and are actuated by hydraulic power supplied by dedicated power control units. The main purpose of the surfaces is to disturb the smooth airflow over the top of the wing, thereby reducing the wings lifting capability. When fully extended, they considerably increase aircraft drag. The maximum deflection angles are greater in the ground mode than the flight mode. With the spoilers in their fully extended position, approximately 80% of the wing/flap lift is destroyed and the aerodynamic drag of the aircraft more than doubles.

content.question: The Mean Aerodynamic Chord (MAC) for a given wing of any planform is...

options.A: the chord of an equivalent untwisted, rectangular wing with the same pitching moment and lift characteristics as the actual wing.
options.B: the chord of a equivalent rectangular wing with the same leading and trailing edge positions as the actual wing half way between the wing root and wing tip.
options.C: the average chord of the aeroplane’s wing, which is used to determine the pitching moment and lift characteristic of the whole wing.
options.D: determined by dividing the actual aeroplane’s wing area by the wing span.

key_points: Mean Aerodynamic Chord The chord line that passes through the geometric center of the plan area (the centroid) of an airfoil is the Mean Aerodynamic Chord (MAC) and for any planform is equal to the chord of a rectangular wing having the same wing span and the same pitching moment and lift
It is usually located at approximately 33% of the semi-span from the wing root
The MAC is often used to reference the location of the center of gravity
learning.explanation: Mean Aerodynamic Chord The chord line that passes through the geometric center of the plan area (the centroid) of an airfoil is the Mean Aerodynamic Chord (MAC) and for any planform is equal to the chord of a rectangular wing having the same wing span and the same pitching moment and lift. It is usually located at approximately 33% of the semi-span from the wing root. The MAC is often used to reference the location of the center of gravity. It is the primary reference for longitudinal stability.

key_points: THE CL v CD POLAR DIAGRAM The polar curve of an aerofoil is the graphical relationship of the coefficients of lift and drag plotted against each other, the resulting graph is as shown in the attached figure

LIFT/DRAG RATIO For any given mass and altitude, level flight can be maintained at any speed, between the maximum and minimum limits, by adjusting the angle of attack to keep the lift formula in balance, to ensure the lift developed is equal to the mass
As the angle of attack increases so does the induced drag, this increases the total drag
learning.explanation: THE CL v CD POLAR DIAGRAM The polar curve of an aerofoil is the graphical relationship of the coefficients of lift and drag plotted against each other, the resulting graph is as shown in the attached figure. LIFT/DRAG RATIO For any given mass and altitude, level flight can be maintained at any speed, between the maximum and minimum limits, by adjusting the angle of attack to keep the lift formula in balance, to ensure the lift developed is equal to the mass. As the angle of attack increases so does the induced drag, this increases the total drag. To counteract the increased total drag a greater amount of thrust is required. This will increase the fuel consumption and is clearly an inefficient way to maintain level flight. The most efficient manner in which to fly an aeroplane is with an angle of attack that creates the greatest amount of lift whilst causing the least amount of drag. The most efficient angle of attack is that which produces the highest lift/drag ratio. This angle of attack is the same for all masses and altitudes and is usually 4º. The EAS at which this occurs is the most economical cruise EAS and varies in direct proportion to the gross mass of the aeroplane. THE EFFECT OF FLAPS Although lift increases with greater flap angles so also does drag, but to a much greater extent, particularly at angles of attack above that which produces the best lift/drag ratio. learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
It acts in the direction of the relative wind
Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Parasite drag is made up out of pressure drag, friction drag and interference drag. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed (with a rate of 1/V²) and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

content.question: Considering the airflow around a positively cambered aerofoil that is producing lift, the point of minimum static pressure is found...

options.A: at the point where the chord line originates from the leading edge.
options.B: where the streamlines are closest together.
options.C: slightly below the point at which the chord line originates from the leading edge.
options.D: at the point of maximum camber on the upper surface.

key_points: When considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow
Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure
Now what is the dynamic pressure and what is static pressure: Dynamic pressure is equal to: q = ½ rho V2
learning.explanation: When considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow. Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure. Now what is the dynamic pressure and what is static pressure: Dynamic pressure is equal to: q = ½ rho V2. Therefore we can say that the dynamic pressure is proportional to the velocity of the airflow. Static pressure is the pressure that any object feels even when not moving. This pressure is caused by the force of gravity forcing particles closer together and pushing against each other and any objects around them. Knowing that dynamic pressure is basically the velocity of the airflow, we can say that if the velocity increase, hence increasing the dynamic pressure, there has to be a reduction in static pressure. This is known as Bernoulli’s principle! Therefore, going back to the question, we can say that the point of minimum static pressure is the point of maximum dynamic pressure (airflow velocity). Therefore the point of minimum static pressure will be somewhere on the top of a positively cambered aerofoil. This would most commonly be at the point of maximum camber, but not always! Changes in angle of attack will move the point of maximum velocity forwards and backwards, therefore the most correct answer is where streamlines are closest together.

key_points: Drag is the force which resists the forward motion of the aircraft
Drag acts parallel to and in the same direction as the relative airflow (in the opposite direction to the flight path)
Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation Induced Drag - the result of lift generation
learning.explanation: Drag is the force which resists the forward motion of the aircraft. Drag acts parallel to and in the same direction as the relative airflow (in the opposite direction to the flight path). Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation Induced Drag - the result of lift generation. Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: - Skin Friction Drag - Form (Pressure) Drag - Interference Drag FORM DRAG Form (pressure) drag results from the pressure at the leading edge of a body being greater than the pressure at the trailing edge. Skin friction, along with the adverse pressure gradient behind the transition will cause a reduction in kinetic energy of the boundary layer. Separation will occur when the boundary layer does not have sufficient kinetic energy in the presence of a given adverse pressure gradient. Because of separation, there will be a lower pressure at the trailing edge than the leading edge. An aerodynamic force will act in the direction of the lower pressure - form drag. When a shock wave forms on the upper surface, the increase of static pressure through the shock wave will create an extreme adverse pressure gradient. If the shock wave is sufficiently strong, separation will occur immediately behind the shock wave.

learning.explanation: CLMAX AUGMENTATION One of the main factors which determine the CLMAX of an aerofoil section is the camber. Increasing the camber of an aerofoil section increases the CL at a given angle of attack and increases CLMAX. TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial. This permits operation at greater weights from given runway lengths and enables greater payloads to be carried. The increase in lift comes mainly from the variation in effective camber that occurs when the flaps are deflected. This alters the lift curve and also produces a higher maximum coefficient of lift. In some instances, the trailing edge flaps may also increase the wing's surface area. Extending the trailing edge flaps alters the pressure distribution around the wing. USE OF TRAILING EDGE FLAPS FOR TAKE-OFF For take-off purposes, the flaps are normally lowered to a position that provides the best lift-drag ratio that can be obtained with the flaps in any position other than fully up. Since the required lift is obtained at a lower airspeed, the take-off run is also reduced. Larger amounts of flap cause a significant increase in drag, which greatly reduces the acceleration and increases the take-off run. The reduced stalling angle of attack and increased drag associated with flaps also reduces the rate and angle of climb.

content.question: What is correct about wingtip vortices? They are...

options.B: Stronger in clean configuration.

options.D: Stronger at high speed.

key_points: WING-TIP VORTICES Wing-tip vortices are created by span-wise airflow over the upper and lower surfaces of a wing/aerofoil that meet at the wing tips as turbulence and therefore induces drag
Span-wise airflow is created because a wing producing lift has a lower static pressure on the upper surface than on the lower surface

At the wing tip, however, there can be no pressure difference, and the pressure is equalized by air flowing around the wing tip from the higher pressure on the lower surface to the lower pressure on the upper surface
learning.explanation: WING-TIP VORTICES Wing-tip vortices are created by span-wise airflow over the upper and lower surfaces of a wing/aerofoil that meet at the wing tips as turbulence and therefore induces drag. Span-wise airflow is created because a wing producing lift has a lower static pressure on the upper surface than on the lower surface. At the wing tip, however, there can be no pressure difference, and the pressure is equalized by air flowing around the wing tip from the higher pressure on the lower surface to the lower pressure on the upper surface. There is therefore a span-wise pressure gradient, i.e., pressure changing along the wing span. One of the primary factors which determine the magnitude of the vortices is the angle of attack. For a given speed, the wing lift, and thus the magnitude of the tip vortices, increases with the angle of attack. Slow, heavy, clean" are the three major conditions generating stronger wing vortices. Extending the flaps increases the coefficient of lift (CL), which means that for a given speed, a lower angle of attack will be required, which reduces the wing tip vortices strength. “Stronger with a high aspect ratio” and “Not related to aspect ratio”. Incorrect. The magnitude of the wingtip vortices is inversely proportional to aspect ratio

learning.explanation: If a symmetrical aerofoil is moving and not producing any lift (i.e. any forces perpendicular to the relative airflow), then it must have zero angle of attack. This helps you visualise the scenario, but in reality, even that knowledge is not required. If an aerofoil is not producing any lift, then it is not producing any lift-induced drag, which is a by-product of lift. learning.explanation: In an aircraft, spoilers can be installed to intentionally reduce lift and increase drag for a specific wing by partially disrupting the airflow over the airfoil. They can extend symmetrically or asymmetrically. If spoilers on both sides are used, its primary purpose is to reduce the speed at which the aircraft is travelling. Spoilers can also be used in a turn to assist the ailerons. In this case, the spoiler mounted on the down-going wing will come up, reducing lift for that wing even more and therefore assisting the ailerons. The spoiler on the up-moving wing will remain stowed. For example, if the aircraft wants to enter a right turn, it will have to bank to the right. The right wing will have to come down and the left wing will have to rise. The aileron on the left will come down, producing more lift on the left wing and the aileron on the right will come up. The spoiler mounted on the upper side of the right wing will also come up, reducing lift of the right wing even more. This way the aircraft reaches its desired bank angle easier at low speeds.

The aircraft system automatically adjusts the approach speed for the reduced flap setting, but does not notify the pilots, so they land with a lower flap setting (less flaps) than planned and computed. The landing distance will (1) _____ due to (2) _____ and (3)_____ being generated by the lower flap setting, and therefore a (4) _____ touchdown speed.

options.A: (1) increase; (2) less drag; (3) less lift; (4) higher
options.B: (1) increase; (2) less drag; (3) more lift; (4) lower
options.C: (1) decrease; (2) less drag; (3) less lift; (4) lower
options.D: (1) increase; (2) more drag; (3) more lift; (4) higher

key_points: Note: This is similar to question 812314, but includes more/less drag as an option
This has been seen as a drop-down menu question in the UK CAA exams
Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Note: This is similar to question 812314, but includes more/less drag as an option. This has been seen as a drop-down menu question in the UK CAA exams. Learning Objective 081.01.09.01.09: Explain the effects of flap-setting errors, such as mis-selection and premature/late extension or retraction of flaps, on: take-off and landing distance and speeds; climb and descent performance; stall buffet margins. This scenario is effectively asking what happens if we land with less flaps. Well of course, with less flaps, our stall speed will be higher, as flaps increase the camber (and sometimes area) of the wing, allowing an aircraft to fly slower with the same amount of lift. With a higher stall speed, the approach speed VREF will be higher, the aircraft will touch down with more groundspeed, causing a longer landing distance than if a higher flap setting were to be used. So that is (1) and (4) answered, and we must remember that with a lower flap setting we have less lift available for the same IAS. This is the component that influences our landing distance, as the lack of lift means we have to fly at a higher speed, and land at a higher speed. As for the drag, lower flap settings produce less drag. This is not the main factor behind the increased landing distance though, as most of the braking action during landing comes from the brakes (and reverse thrust, if available), and the flaps actually reduce the weight of the aircraft on the wheels, so reduce braking ability slightly.

content.question: Assuming incompressible flow, when considering streamlines in the vicinity of an aerofoil, which of the following answers is correct?

options.A: Converging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is increasing and that the static pressure is decreasing.
options.B: Diverging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is decreasing and that the static pressure is decreasing.
options.C: Diverging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is increasing and that the static pressure is increasing.
options.D: Converging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is decreasing and that the static pressure is increasing.

key_points: When considering streamlines, we can say that converging streamlines indicate an increasing airflow velocity, and diverging lines indicate a decreasing airflow velocity
Now when considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow
Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure
learning.explanation: When considering streamlines, we can say that converging streamlines indicate an increasing airflow velocity, and diverging lines indicate a decreasing airflow velocity. Now when considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow. Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure. Now what is the dynamic pressure and what is static pressure: Dynamic pressure is equal to: q = ½ rho V2. Therefore we can say that the dynamic pressure is proportional to the velocity of the airflow. Static pressure is the pressure that any object feels even when not moving. This pressure is caused by the force of gravity forcing particles closer together and pushing against each other and any objects around them. Knowing that dynamic pressure is basically the velocity of the airflow, we can say that if the velocity increase, hence increasing the dynamic pressure, there has to be a reduction in static pressure. This is known as Bernoulli’s principle! What this means for our question is that: Converging streamlines indicate a speed increase Diverging streamlines indicated a speed decrease A decrease in static pressure occurs with an increasing speed And an increase in static pressure occurs with a decreasing speed

This has nothing to do with induced drag. 2) Propeller slipstream over the wing. – Incorrect The slipstream from a propeller will cause a couple effects, such as yaw, and torque, but it will have no effect on induced drag. 3) Aerodynamic interaction between aeroplane parts. – Incorrect The drag because of aerodynamic interaction between aeroplane parts is known as interfrerence drag, and has nothing to do with induced drag. 4) Downwash generated by tip vortices. – Correct Firstly, one could simply deduce the correct answer through cancelling out the incorrect answer. content.question: At a load factor of 1 and the aeroplane's minimum drag speed, what is the ratio between induced drag DI and parasite drag DP?

options.A: DI / DP = 2.
options.B: DI / DP = 1 / 2.
options.C: DI / DP = 1.
options.D: It varies between aeroplane types.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air
It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

content.question: Skin friction drag is caused by the...

options.A: air’s viscosity producing shear forces within the boundary layer.
options.B: difference in pressure acting on the aerofoil’s surface in the direction of flight.
options.C: loss of momentum within an airflow caused by the aerofoil changing the flow direction.
options.D: friction between the surface and the air molecules in direct contact with the surface.

key_points: Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation, and Induced Drag - the result of lift generation
Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: Skin Friction Drag Form (Pressure) Drag, and Interference Drag NOTE: Skin Friction and Form Drag are together known as PROFILE DRAG
Boundary Layer Skin friction drag is a function of the layer of air closest to the surface
learning.explanation: Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation, and Induced Drag - the result of lift generation. Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: Skin Friction Drag Form (Pressure) Drag, and Interference Drag NOTE: Skin Friction and Form Drag are together known as PROFILE DRAG. Boundary Layer Skin friction drag is a function of the layer of air closest to the surface. As air flows over a wing, the roughness of the surface and the viscous property of the air itself slow it down. Much like fluids, the more viscous the air, the greater its retardation. At the surface, the air particles adhere to it and their relative velocity is reduced to zero (figure 1). Just above the surface, the air particles slow down due to the friction effects between the particles, but except for the layer in contact with the surface, the particles do not completely come to rest. The relative velocity of the air particles increases steadily with distance from the surface, until reaching a point where the particles do not slow up at all and instead travel at the free stream velocity. The boundary layer is the layer of air between the surface and the free stream velocity in which local retardation takes place. Like the main airflow, the boundary layer flow can be either laminar or turbulent in nature (figure 2). Skin Friction Drag Skin friction is the reaction to the retardation of the airflow within the boundary layer. The retarded air tries to drag the surface along with the flow, in much the same way as two solid surfaces sliding over each other do. Known as shear stress, this is directly proportional to the speed of flow. Figure 3 represents the shear stress patterns that exist between layers. The gradual velocity change associated with the laminar boundary layer shows that low shear stresses exist near the surface, resulting in low skin friction drag. Conversely, the rapid velocity change associated with the turbulent boundary layer is evidence of high skin friction drag.

content.question: Which plane and situation experiences the least amount of lift reduction?

options.A: High wing on take-off
options.B: Low wing on take-off
options.C: High wing on landing
options.D: Low wing on landing

key_points: Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings
Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices
This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack
learning.explanation: Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack. It also alters the pressure distribution around the wing and the amount of lift developed. This occurs because the change in effective angle of attack increases the wing’s coefficient of lift (CL) and thus its lifting capability at any given angle of attack. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, also determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. (figure 2) THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON LANDING When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tailplane. THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON TAKE-OFF During the take-off phase of flight, as the aircraft leaves ground effect the wing tip vortices rapidly grow in magnitude producing an increase in downwash behind the wing. This causes a reduction in the lift produced at a given angle of attack and the associated rapid increase in induced drag may prevent a successful take-off. The increased downwash acting on the tailplane increases the download, resulting in a nose-up pitching moment. The high wing aircraft will still experience ground effect, but because the wing is several feet farther from the runway, the total effect on the aircraft is greatly reduced, as ground effect decreases exponentially with difference from the runway surface. Thus, a high wing on take-off is the configuration with the least reduction in lift.

learning.explanation: For a fixed wing aircraft, ground effect is the increased lift and decreased drag that the wings generate when they are close to the ground. Upon landing, ground effect can give the effect of floating. The stall speed may be temporarily reduced due to ground effect. Ground effect is effective from the ground to approximately half the aircraft’s wingspan above ground. The effect is caused by the ground interrupting the wingtip vortices, decreasing the downwash angle. Below the airfoil, a higher pressure than if an airfoil travels at higher altitude is created, as the air below the airfoil is trapped in between the wing and the ground. This means that the aircraft needs a lower angle of attack for a certain amount of lift. This results in lower induced drag (decreasing induced angle of attack).

learning.explanation: An alternative to increasing the angle of attack to increase lift is to lower trailing-edge flaps provided the speed is at or below the maximum speed for lowering flap (VFO). This effectively increases the camber of the wing, the angle of attack and the coefficient of lift. However, the thrust may have to be increased to overcome the increased drag, even though when deployed they decrease the magnitude of the wing-tip vortices. Not only does the extension of trailing-edge flaps decrease the critical angle of attack it also increases the CLMAX, increases the total lift generated, increases the total drag, unfavorably affects the lift/drag ratio and decreases the stalling speed no matter what the altitude or mass of the airplane. Unlike slats, trailing-edge flaps increase lift at all angles of attack up to the stall. Thus, if the angle of attack remains constant during flap extension the airplane will begin to climb. All trailing-edge flaps when lowered, increase the acceleration of the airflow over the upper surface of the wing, which reduces the pressure above the wing and increases the upwash over the leading edge. Together these influences generate an increased nose-down pitching moment because of the altered pressure distribution around the flaps and the aft movement of the wing CP.

key_points: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil
- increase the roughness of the aircraft surface
- increase the weight of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil. - increase the roughness of the aircraft surface. - increase the weight of the aircraft. Ice will normally form on and around the leading edges of wings and tailplane and can result in severe distortion of the leading edge profile. This will give a large increase in drag and a substantial decrease in CLMAX. The skin friction drag will increase and the boundary layer will have an earlier separation, giving a reduced critical angle of attack, thereby a higher stall speed. Ice builds up on an aircraft when the super-cooled water droplets (SCWDs) hit the cold airframe and freeze onto the surface. This will happen most in particular sections of the aircraft, such as the leading edges of the wings, the nose, propeller spinners, the tail leading edges, and any protrusions such as the windshield, pitot tubes, AoA vanes, etc. This effect is much more pronounced when the items are sharp, instead of curved. Take a wing for example: when it is a very curved wing, useful for low speed flight, it will have a leading edge with a large radius, and the pressure waves that propagate from the front of the wing during flight are effectively giving the air advanced warming that the wing is coming, so it can move out of the way. This means that the SCWDs also move out of the way, so do not hit the wing as much. This means that sharp wings (with a smaller radius - used for higher speed flight) give less of a "warning" to the air, and the SCWDs will not move out of the way as much, thereby causing more ice accretion. This is the same for sharp protrusions such as the AoA vanes and pitot tubes.

An ice-contaminated wing will stall at a lower angle of attack (decreased critical AOA) or higher airspeed (increased stall speed) than a clean wing

learning.explanation: Any deposit of ice, snow or frost on the external surfaces of an aeroplane, except as permitted in the flight manual, may drastically affect its performance due to reduced aerodynamic lift and increased drag resulting from the disturbed airflow. An ice-contaminated wing will stall at a lower angle of attack (decreased critical AOA) or higher airspeed (increased stall speed) than a clean wing. Minute amounts of ice (equivalent to medium grit sandpaper) covering the leading edges or upper surfaces of wings can increase the stall speed up to 15 kt. Ice will also increase the weight and, therefore the stall speed also increases, because a higher angle of attack is required to produce an increased lift. content.question:
Refer to figure.
The diagram shows the parameter X against TAS. If horizontal flight is considered axis X represents:

options.A: the parasite drag.
options.B: the total drag.
options.C: the lift force.
options.D: the induced drag.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air
It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

key_points: Be careful with this question! Mass flow can be defined by: Mass flow rate = density x velocity x cross section are And we know that: Mass flow rate = constant Assuming constant velocity, we can say that an increase in temperature will decrease the air density and therefore decrease the mass flow
However this question does not specify that the velocity remains constant
Now let’s create a situation that follows all the specified parameters of the question
learning.explanation: Be careful with this question! Mass flow can be defined by: Mass flow rate = density x velocity x cross section are And we know that: Mass flow rate = constant Assuming constant velocity, we can say that an increase in temperature will decrease the air density and therefore decrease the mass flow. However this question does not specify that the velocity remains constant. Now let’s create a situation that follows all the specified parameters of the question. Let’s say we have a tube with steady low subsonic flow. Halfway through this pipe we have a heating element that heats up the air, this will decrease the density of the airflow. So that means we have less mass flow right? Well no because mass flow will naturally always keep itself constant, therefore if the density of the air decreases without any change in cross section area, the velocity will increase. This is because the mass flow on the entry side of the tube will always be the same as the mass flow on the exit side of the tube, even if the air is warmer/colder. Therefore, assuming no constant velocity is specified, any change in temperature will not affect the flow rate.

learning.explanation: Note: this question has had to be slightly modified from the original feedback for clarity and correctness. Please send any further exam feedback to us in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you. Learning Objective 081.01.10.01.02: Describe the effect of spoilers on the CL-alpha graph and stall speed. Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect on the critical angle of attack is much more complicated, however, and is not always easy to predict. As the spoiler pushes up into the airflow, the adverse pressure gradient over it (which usually causes the stall) is reduced and the airflow is re-energised, but the area behind the spoiler (most do not go all the way to the trailing edge of the wing) is automatically stalled after a small spoiler deflection, due to the gap created. So there are two opposing forces at play: Spoilers act a little bit like an up-going aileron, re-energising the airflow and increasing the critical AoA, The large stalled area behind the spoiler decreases the critical AoA. Therefore, it is difficult to say what effect spoiler deflection will have on the critical AoA. Some sources mention a slight decrease in critical AoA overall, but it appears that EASA have published other questions where the overall effect is an increase in the critical AoA due to spoiler extension, so we have stuck with this across all questions, as it seems likely that the examiner wants this answer (and feedback has agreed with this in the past). In this case though, the graph given in the question removes all uncertainty, and an increase in critical AoA is the only possible correct answer. Of course, the real answer is certain to depend on the proportion of the wing, the size and location of the spoiler, and most importantly, the amount of spoiler deflection. As this is so complex, the examiner’s choice of answer is all that truly matters here.

When a flap is deflected downwards, the camber of the airfoil increases, the coefficient of lift (CL) increases, resulting in higher lift production. However, to maintain a constant altitude, the increased lift needs to be compensated by reducing the airspeed (V), as stated in the question. In simple terms, when the flaps are deployed, CL increases (CL higher than 0.28), but to keep the lift balanced and the altitude constant, the aircraft slows down (V decreases). As a result, even with the increased CL from the flaps, the overall lift remains the same.

learning.explanation: Speedbrakes (flight spoilers) are secondary flight control surfaces that can be deployed manually by the pilot. Dependent upon the aircraft type, the speed brake(s) may consist of a single panel or symetrically mounted pairs of panels. In most cases, speedbrakes are panels (most frequently on the upper surface of the wing, but sometimes mounted on the fuselage top side or left/right side near the tail) which, when selected by the pilot, extend into the airstream to produce drag. Their operating principle is simple. Cross-sectional area increases, the air becomes turbulent in the space directly behind them, which increases parasite drag. The wing-mounted versions of speedbrakes also dump some lift and thereby increase induced drag also as the wing has to fly at a higher angle of attack (though not all speed brakes are of this type, so it is not the correct answer). content.question: Which combination produces the least amount of induced drag?

options.B: High wing at landing.
options.C: Low wing at take-off.

key_points: Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings
Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices
This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack
learning.explanation: Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack. It also alters the pressure distribution around the wing and the amount of lift developed. This occurs because the change in effective angle of attack increases the wing’s coefficient of lift (CL) and thus its lifting capability at any given angle of attack. THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON LANDING When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tailplane. THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON TAKE-OFF During the take-off phase of flight, as the aircraft leaves ground effect the wing tip vortices rapidly grow in magnitude producing an increase in downwash behind the wing. This causes a reduction in the lift produced at a given angle of attack and the associated rapid increase in induced drag may prevent a successful take-off. The increased downwash acting on the tailplane increases the download, resulting in a nose-up pitching moment. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. Thus, a low wing aircraft on landing will produce the least amount of Induced Drag. content.question: According to the equation of continuity, the constant mass flow in a stream tube is dependent on the following for a low subsonic flow, assuming that the air is incompressible:

key_points: To demonstrate the effect the Principle of Continuity has on aerodynamic theory, we consider a streamline flow of air through a tube, which has a reduced cross-sectional area in the middle
The air mass flow, or mass per unit time (kg/m3), through the tube will be the product of the cross-sectional area (A), the airflow velocity (V), and the air density (ρ)
Mass flow will remain a constant value at all points along the tube
learning.explanation: To demonstrate the effect the Principle of Continuity has on aerodynamic theory, we consider a streamline flow of air through a tube, which has a reduced cross-sectional area in the middle. The air mass flow, or mass per unit time (kg/m3), through the tube will be the product of the cross-sectional area (A), the airflow velocity (V), and the air density (ρ). Mass flow will remain a constant value at all points along the tube. The equation of continuity is: A x V x ρ = Constant Because air is a compressible fluid, any pressure change in the flow will affect the air density. However, at low subsonic speeds (< M 0.4 or Mach 0.4, i.e., aircraft speed is 40% of the local speed of sound), density changes will be insignificant and can be disregarded. The equation of continuity can now be simplified to: A x V = Constant ⇒ V ≈ 1/A Because the mass flow must remain constant, it can be seen from the equation of continuity that the reduction in the tube’s cross-sectional area results in an increase in velocity, and vice versa.

Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: Skin Friction Drag Form (Pressure) Drag, and Interference Drag NOTE: Skin Friction and Form Drag are together known as PROFILE DRAG. Form drag is produced whenever the streamline airflow passing over an aircraft separates from the surface and becomes turbulent. An example of extreme form drag is the effect of a flat plate placed at right angles to the airflow. The pressure immediately in front of the plate is above atmospheric, whilst the pressure behind the plate is below atmospheric. This results in a sucking effect behind the plate and the formation of vortices. The more rapidly the airflow changes direction, the greater the pressure gradient, the earlier the separation, and the higher the form drag. Changing the shape, or streamline, of a given object reduces drag by delaying the point at which the airflow separates.

learning.explanation: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil. - increase the roughness of the aircraft surface. - increase the weight of the aircraft. The CL of an aerofoil increases with angle of attack up to a maximum (CLMAX). Any further increase above this stalling angle, or critical angle of attack, will make it impossible for the airflow to smoothly follow the upper wing contour, and the flow will separate from the surface, causing CL to decrease and drag to increase rapidly. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. The formation of ice along a wing's leading edge greatly alters its aerodynamic contour and leads to premature separation of the boundary layer. This reduces the wing's stalling angle of attack and also its maximum coefficient of lift by up to 50% The increase in stall speed due to ice formation is not easy to quantify, as the accumulation and shape of the iceformation is impossible to predict. Ice or frost must never be allowed to remain on any aerodynamic surfaces in flight, nor must ice, frost, snow or other contamination be allowed to remain on the aircraft immediately before flight.

key_points: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift
The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing
This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag
learning.explanation: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift. The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing. This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag. The shape of an airfoil has a huge impact on the induced drag of an aircraft assuming the same weight and speed. This question is asking for the effect of: Lift distribution: An elliptical lift distribution generates less induced drag than a rectangular lift distribution. This is because the lift distribution of a rectangular wing creates a larger force near the tip. Even though the elliptical wing creates a larger coefficient of lift at the tip, the subsequently smaller wing area near the tip means that barely any force of lift is created there any therefore leads to a smaller vortex and less induced drag. Therefore statement 1 is correct! Aspect ratio: Induced drag is inversely proportional to the aspect ratio. Therefore, induced drag increases with decreasing aspect ratio, and, induced drag decreases with increasing aspect ratio. Therefore statement 2 is incorrect!

learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD). Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. Flying at a slower speed than VMD (back side), the aircraft will be in the unstable speed region. Any loss of speed will result in an increase in drag and further speed loss (which must be corrected by an increase in thrust). The sudden change to a tailwind (or a decrease in headwind) can cause a loss of airspeed. Flying at a faster speed than VMD (front side), the aircraft will be in the stable speed region. Any loss of speed will result in an decrease in drag. This decrease in drag will allow the speed to increase and recover the original speed. The sudden change to a tailwind (or a decrease in headwind) can cause a loss of airspeed.

key_points: SYMMETRICAL AEROFOIL The distribution of pressure is important in aerodynamics, since it determines: - The amount of lift generated - Any pitching moments - The form drag of an aerofoil section The lift and drag forces of a wing cross-section are dependent on the pressure distribution around the wing
The pressure distribution around an aerofoil is the resultant of the angle of the aerofoil chordline to the oncoming airflow, the angle of attack
If a symmetrical aerofoil section is in a steady airstream at zero degrees Angle of Attack, a stagnation point forms on the leading edge
learning.explanation: SYMMETRICAL AEROFOIL The distribution of pressure is important in aerodynamics, since it determines: - The amount of lift generated - Any pitching moments - The form drag of an aerofoil section The lift and drag forces of a wing cross-section are dependent on the pressure distribution around the wing. The pressure distribution around an aerofoil is the resultant of the angle of the aerofoil chordline to the oncoming airflow, the angle of attack. If a symmetrical aerofoil section is in a steady airstream at zero degrees Angle of Attack, a stagnation point forms on the leading edge. The airflow velocity above and below the aerofoil increases by an equal amount and the static pressures reduce by an equal amount. Consequently, no pressure differential exists, and no net lift is created. CLMAX AUGMENTATION One of the main factors which determine the CLMAX of an aerofoil section is the camber. Increasing the camber of an aerofoil section increases the CL at a given angle of attack and increases CLMAX. TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial. This permits operation at greater weights from given runway lengths and enables greater payloads to be carried. Returning the flaps to their neutral position when no longer required, returns the wing to its former aerodynamic characteristics. The increase in lift comes mainly from the variation in effective camber that occurs when the flaps are deflected. This alters the lift curve and also produces a higher maximum coefficient of lift. In some instances, the trailing edge flaps may also increase the wing's surface area. Extending the trailing edgeflaps alters the pressure distribution around the wing. LEADING EDGE DEVICES Leading edge devices increase maximum value of CL and critical angle of attack. But for the constant angle of attack CL is the same or less. (Curve extends to the right and up).

content.question: In ground effect, the induced angle of attack (1) _____, causing the coefficient of induced drag to (2) _____.

options.B: (1) increases; (2) decreases

options.D: (1) decreases; (2) increases

key_points: When an airplane flies at a very low height over the ground (around 50% of the length of the wingspan), the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved
A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences around a 50% reduction of its total drag
This phenomenon is ground effect
learning.explanation: When an airplane flies at a very low height over the ground (around 50% of the length of the wingspan), the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences around a 50% reduction of its total drag. This phenomenon is ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tail plane. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, also determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. Aircraft entering ground effect: Downwash decreases. The effective angle of attack increases. Increased lift during landing if the angle of attack remains constant. The induced angle of attack decreases. Induced drag (and induced drag coefficient) decreases. Aircraft leaving ground effect: The effective angle of attack decreases. Decreased lift during take-off if the angle of attack remains constant. Induced drag increases. Downwash increases. The induced angle of attack increases.

content.question: What happens to induced drag when airspeed increases?

options.A: Induced drag increases.
options.B: Induced drag decreases.
options.C: Induced drag remains the same.
options.D: Induced drag is not affected by airspeed.

key_points: INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips
The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft
It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated
learning.explanation: INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft. It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated. To replace the lift lost by the increased downwash, the aircraft must be flown at a higher angle of attack. This increases drag. This extra drag is called induced drag. The stronger the vortices, the greater the induced drag. INDUCED DRAG vs. AIRSPEED The Effect of Airspeed relates to the changes in induced drag with the variation of airspeed. Induced drag is most significant at low airspeeds and high angles of attack (i.e. during take-off and landing, when it can account for approximately three-quarters of the total drag). To maintain steady level flight, as the airspeed decreases and the angle of attack increases, the slower passage of air rearward over the wing increases the spanwise flow of air around the wing tip. This results in larger wing tip vortices and greater induced drag.

content.question: In straight and level flight, the spanwise flow on an unswept wing is from the...

options.A: lower surface via the trailing edge to the upper wing surface.
options.B: lower surface to the upper surface via the wing tip.
options.C: upper surface via the trailing edge to the lower wing surface.
options.D: upper surface to the lower surface via the wing tip.

key_points: Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips
The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centerline of the aircraft
The third dimensional flow is the movement of air laterally as it moves to the aft edge of the airfoil
learning.explanation: Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centerline of the aircraft. The third dimensional flow is the movement of air laterally as it moves to the aft edge of the airfoil. This is called spanwise flow. As caused by its movement through the air, is that for all positive angles of attack in level flight there is an excess area of low pressure above the upper surface of the airfoil. Thus, air will flow from the relatively high pressure under the lower surface around the wing tip to the lower pressure over the upper surface. Consequently, the flow of air moves outward from the wing root towards the wing tip on the lower surface and from the tip inwards towards the wing root on the upper surface. This is spanwise flow and is a slightly diagonal movement of the rearward airflow. Thus, the airflow over the two surfaces is moving in different directions when they meet at the trailing edge of the airfoil causing vortices to form along its entire length.

options.B: (1) increase; (2) decrease; (3) parasite.

key_points: Drag is the force which resists the forward motion of the aircraft
Drag acts parallel to and in the same direction as the relative airflow (in the opposite direction to the flight path)
Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: INDUCED DRAG - the result of lift generation
learning.explanation: Drag is the force which resists the forward motion of the aircraft. Drag acts parallel to and in the same direction as the relative airflow (in the opposite direction to the flight path). Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: INDUCED DRAG - the result of lift generation. PARASITE DRAG - independent of lift generation. Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: - Skin Friction Drag - Form (Pressure) Drag - Interference Drag The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum DragSpeed (VMD). Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. PARASITE DRAG If an aircraft were flying at zero lift angle of attack, the only drag present would be parasite drag. FORM DRAG Form drag is produced whenever the streamline airflow passing over an aircraft separates from the surface and becomes turbulent. An example of extreme form drag is the effect of a flat plate placed at right angles to the airflow. EFFECT OF CONFIGURATION ON TOTAL DRAG Extension of the landing gear, air brakes, or flaps will increase parasite drag but will not substantially affect induced drag. The effect of increasing parasite drag is to increase total drag at any IAS but to decrease the speed VMD compared to the clean aircraft.

content.question: A crew plan for a full flap landing (30⁰) but, due to distraction, fail to extend flaps from the approach to the landing setting until a few seconds before touchdown. Which of the following statements is correct assuming the correct glidepath was flown to touchdown?

options.A: The aircraft is likely to float and touch down further along the runway.
options.B: There is no problem if the aircraft attitude is not changed.
options.C: There is less risk of a hard landing.
options.D: A go-around is unnecessary.

key_points: Note: There are quite a few factors which affect an aircraft's landing performance and handling
The question and available options do not take into account these different factors
That is to say that the examiner has been very closed minded in writing this question, using a "tunnel vision" approach
learning.explanation: Note: There are quite a few factors which affect an aircraft's landing performance and handling. The question and available options do not take into account these different factors. That is to say that the examiner has been very closed minded in writing this question, using a "tunnel vision" approach. The current correct option is simply the only answer that makes any sense. It is the "most correct" out of a bad bunch, and in itself is arguable, but depending on the circumstances we have not been told, may be true, whereas the other answers are not true in any circumstance. For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the wing’s effective camber and the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. Flap extension during landings provides several advantages by: producing greater lift and permitting lower landing speed; producing greater drag, permitting a steep descent angle without airspeed increase, therefore Reducing the length of the landing roll. Therefore, the answer here is that using less flaps than expected will cause significantly less drag than expected, so the aircraft may float for a while longer, and therefore have a longer landing roll (that is assuming that the pilot rotates enough during the flare, which has not been specified in the question). As mentioned above, none of the other answers could be correct: There will be a large difference to the handling characteristics, even if the attitude remains the same. There is arguably a higher risk of a hard landing due to the lower "cushioning" effect of the lower flap setting. This one takes longer to explain but most pilots know it naturally from experience. A go-around is very much advised if you realise the flaps are incorrectly set at a low altitude where this cannot be fixed.

Secondarily, they are useful for increasing drag, but that is not the purpose of this question.
