key_points: As we want to remain in straight and level flight, we know for sure that the lift required will remains constant
Now that we know that lift remains constant, looking at the lift formula: L = CL ½ rho v2 S We can tell that to remain equal, as the speed is increasing we need to either decrease S or CL

learning.explanation: As we want to remain in straight and level flight, we know for sure that the lift required will remains constant. Now that we know that lift remains constant, looking at the lift formula: L = CL ½ rho v2 S We can tell that to remain equal, as the speed is increasing we need to either decrease S or CL. Now assuming we don’t change any flaps settings, its clear we need to reduce the coefficient of lift. Reducing the coefficient of lift means applying a smaller angle of attack (AoA). learning.explanation: STAGNATION POINT In aerodynamics, the stagnation point is the point in a flow field where the local velocity of the fluid (in our case the atmosphere) is zero. If we increase the angle of attack, the stagnation point will move down, causing more air to move upwards over the upper side of the wing and moving the point of lowest static pressure forwards. content.question: Induced drag may be reduced by:

options.A: the use of a wing tip with a much thinner aerofoil.
options.B: an increase in aspect ratio.
options.C: a decrease of the aspect ratio.
options.D: an increase in wing sweep back.

key_points: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag
This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient
If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag. This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient. If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices. Another factor increasing wing tip vortices is the aspect ratio (λ) of the wing. This is the ratio of the wing span to its mean chord. The aspect ratio of the wing is equal to the square of the wingspan divided by the wing surface area. Therefore a short but wide wing has a low aspect ratio but a long, narrow wing has a high aspect ratio. With a lower aspect ratio, the induced drag is higher, thus increasing wing tip vortices. With a high aspect ratio, the induced drag is lower, reducing wing tip vortices. We can therefore state that the relationship between wing tip vortices and aspect ratio is inversely proportional. A wing with a higher aspect ratio has a lower value for CLMAX and will have a higher value of CL for a certain angle of attack.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which of the figures shows the change in the total drag graph when density altitude is increased?

options.A: Figure 1.
options.B: Figure 2.
options.C: Figure 3.
options.D: Figure 4.

key_points: When density altitude increases, the air gets "thinner", meaning that there are less air particles per cubic metre, and therefore less air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown
This would decrease lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS
However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure
learning.explanation: When density altitude increases, the air gets "thinner", meaning that there are less air particles per cubic metre, and therefore less air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown. This would decrease lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS. However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure. This value measures the amount of air particles hitting the aircraft, and their speed. If we fly at a constant IAS, but climb higher in the atmosphere, the lower air density means that we have to fly faster to get the same amount of dynamic pressure, meaning the same amount of air particles over the wing, etc. This is an increase in TAS (True Airspeed) for a constant IAS. IAS directly controls our drag and our lift, as they vary proportionally to dynamic pressure, see the lift or drag equation for the mathematical proof here, it is very easy to spot. D = (1/2 x ρ x V2)x CD x S As dynamic pressure is 1/2 x ρ x V2, which is measured by the IAS, then drag is directly proportional to IAS, coefficient of drag, and surface area. If the graph was for total drag against IAS, then the curve would remain in exactly the same position with increased altitude (ignoring compressibility at very high altitudes). As the X-axis on the graphs is TAS, not IAS, then with an increase in altitude, the drag curve will look the same, but will be shifted to the right, due to the increased TAS for the same IAS at higher altitudes, but as the same forces of drag exist at each point on the curve, the curve will not move up or down. The answer is therefore figure 3, moving to the right.

learning.explanation: In some wing designs, separation tends to occur first in the region of the tip, reducing lift in those areas. To give favourable stall characteristics, a tapered wing must be modified using one or more of the following: Geometric twist (washout), a decrease in incidence from root to tip. They work two-fold to increase drag. Not only do they increase the frontal area to provide parasite drag, they also spoil some of the lifting effect of that portion of wing, and therefore the aircraft has to pitch up to fly at a higher angle of attack, which produces extra induced drag. Operationally, they are mostly used to remove energy in the descent, this is either by slowing the aircraft down faster in level flight, by increasing the descent rate, or a bit of both.

key_points: Coefficient of lift (CL) is a dimensionless coefficient and is the lifting ability of a particular wing

This equation is simply a rearrangement of the lift equation where we solve for the lift coefficient in terms of the other variables
learning.explanation: Coefficient of lift (CL) is a dimensionless coefficient and is the lifting ability of a particular wing. It depends on both the shape of the wing section (fixed design feature) and the angle of attack. This equation is simply a rearrangement of the lift equation where we solve for the lift coefficient in terms of the other variables. The lift coefficient CL is equal to the lift L divided by the quantity: density times half the velocity V squared times the wing area A. learning.explanation: When considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow. Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure. Now what is the dynamic pressure and what is static pressure: Dynamic pressure is equal to: q = ½ rho V2. Therefore we can say that the dynamic pressure is proportional to the velocity of the airflow. Static pressure is the pressure that any object feels even when not moving. This pressure is caused by the force of gravity forcing particles closer together and pushing against each other and any objects around them. Knowing that dynamic pressure is basically the velocity of the airflow, we can say that if the velocity increase, hence increasing the dynamic pressure, there has to be a reduction in static pressure. This is known as Bernoulli’s principle! Going back to the question, we can say that the point of minimum static pressure is the point of maximum dynamic pressure (airflow velocity). Therefore the point of minimum static pressure will be somewhere on the top of a positively cambered aerofoil.

key_points: Terminology definition angle of attack: angle between the chord line and the relative (undisturbed) air flow
Local airflow = downwash at the trailing edge of the airfoil for example

Angle of attack (AOA, α - Greek letter alpha) is a term used in aerodynamics to describe the angle between the chord line of an airfoil and the vector representing the relative motion between the airfoil and the air through which it is moving
learning.explanation: Terminology definition angle of attack: angle between the chord line and the relative (undisturbed) air flow. Local airflow = downwash at the trailing edge of the airfoil for example. Angle of attack (AOA, α - Greek letter alpha) is a term used in aerodynamics to describe the angle between the chord line of an airfoil and the vector representing the relative motion between the airfoil and the air through which it is moving. For a two-dimensional airfoil, angle of attack is the angle between the chord line and the direction of arrival of the incoming air. In aviation, angle of attack is used to describe the angle between the chord line of the (three dimensional) wing of a fixed-wing aircraft and the vector representing the relative motion between the aircraft and the atmosphere. Since a wing can have twist, a chord line of the whole wing may not be definable, so an alternate reference line is simply defined. Often, the chord line of the root of the wing is chosen as the reference line. The angle of attack is often confused with the pitch angle of an aircraft and the angle of incidence. Pitch angle and angle of incidence are measured from the same reference line as angle of attack (conceptually the chord line), but pitch refers to the horizon and angle of incidence to the longitudinal axis of the aeroplane. Whereas, the angle of attack is measured from the (same) reference line to the direction of the arrival of the air to the wing (caused by the relative motion between the wing and the atmosphere). Note: Some tricky questions ask about the angle of attack of the aeroplane (not the wing) => angle between speed vector and longitudinal axis.

options.B: The difference in winglet size does not affect the impact of ground effect.
options.C: Aircraft A is LESS affected by the change of induced drag compared to Aircraft B as bigger winglets REDUCE wingtip vortices.

key_points: Note: This appears to be a scenario based version of an older question, number 818975
When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan, the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved
A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, can experience up to a 50% reduction of its total drag
learning.explanation: Note: This appears to be a scenario based version of an older question, number 818975. When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan, the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, can experience up to a 50% reduction of its total drag. This phenomenon is called ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices and reduces the strength of downwash. When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in downforce on the tail plane. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, also determines the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any give angle of attack. Any devices that reduce induced drag will cause ground effect to be less effective, as the induced drag is already lowered. Winglets (or fitting bigger winglets) on an aircraft reduce the size and strength of wingtip vortices, and therefore reduce the induced drag in all stages of flight. Therefore, aircraft A with bigger winglets will not feel as much of a reduction in induced drag during ground effect, therefore the ground effect will be decreased on aircraft A. To put it simply, winglets and ground effect do the same job, and ground effect cannot do as much when (bigger) winglets are already fitted.

options.B: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift
The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing
This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag
learning.explanation: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift. The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing. This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag. This question is asking for the effect of: Angle of attack: The induced drag is proportional to the angle of attack. Therefore, induced drag increases as the angle of attack increases, and, induced drag decreases and the angle of attack decreases. This is because, to maintain lift constant, as the velocity decreases, the coefficient of lift will have to be increased. This is achieve by increasing the angle of attack. At higher coefficients of lift, the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing will be greater and therefore produce stronger vortices = stronger induced drag. (and vice versa) Changing mass: Induced drag is proportional to the mass. Therefore, induced drag increases with increasing aeroplane mass, and, induced drag decreases with decreasing aeroplane mass. This is because, as the aircraft get heavier, the lift that the wings will have to produce increases. To achieve that, the coefficient of lift will have to increase, meaning a higher AoA, which creates stronger vortices. (and vice versa) Summary: Higher AR = Lower induced drag Higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher weight = higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher speed = lower AoA = lower induced drag Winglets = lower induced drag.

learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag. This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient. If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices. Another factor increasing wing tip vortices is the aspect ratio (λ) of the wing. This is the ratio of the wing span to its mean chord. The aspect ratio of the wing is equal to the square of the wingspan divided by the wing surface area. Therefore a short but wide wing has a low aspect ratio but a long, narrow wing has a high aspect ratio. With a lower aspect ratio, the induced drag is higher, thus increasing wing tip vortices. With a high aspect ratio, the induced drag is lower, reducing wing tip vortices. We can therefore state that the relationship between wing tip vortices and aspect ratio is inversely proportional. A wing with a higher aspect ratio has a lower value for CLMAX and will have a higher value of CL for a certain angle of attack.

learning.explanation: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect on the critical angle of attack is much more complicated, however, and is not always easy to predict. As the spoiler pushes up into the airflow, the adverse pressure gradient over it (which usually causes the stall) is reduced and the airflow is re-energised, but the area behind the spoiler (most do not go all the way to the trailing edge of the wing) is automatically stalled after a small spoiler deflection, due to the gap created. So there are two opposing forces at play: Spoilers act a little bit like an up-going aileron, re-energising the airflow and increasing the critical AoA, The large stalled area behind the spoiler decreases the critical AoA. Therefore, it is difficult to say what effect spoiler deflection will have on the critical AoA. Some sources mention a slight decrease in critical AoA overall, but EASA have published questions like this one where the overall effect is an increase in the critical AoA due to spoiler extension, so we have stuck with this across all questions, as it seems likely that the examiner wants this answer (and feedback has agreed with this in the past). In this case though, the graph given in the question removes all uncertainty, and the only answer is that the graph follows the “B” direction, down and to the right. Of course, the real answer is certain to depend on the proportion of the wing, the size and location of the spoiler, and most importantly, the amount of spoiler deflection. As this is so complex, the examiner’s choice of answer is all that truly matters here.

Which of these statements about the strength of wing tip vortices are correct or incorrect?

options.B: I is incorrect, II is correct.

key_points: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift
They are caused by the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing, which causes an updraft of high pressure air around the tip of the wing
This updraft turn into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift. They are caused by the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing, which causes an updraft of high pressure air around the tip of the wing. This updraft turn into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex. The higher the pressure difference between the top and bottom of the wing, the stronger the vortices. This question is specifically asking for: Angle of attack: The strength of the vortices (and therefore also induced drag) is proportional to the angle of attack. Therefore; the strength of the vortices increase as the angle of attack increases. And also; the strength of the vortices decrease as the angle of attack decreases. Therefore statement 1 is correct! Aspect ratio: The strength of the vortices is inversely proportional with the aspect ratio. Meaning that the strength of the wing tip vortices increase as the aspect ratio decreases. And vice versa: the strength decreases as the aspect ratio increases. Therefore statement 2 is correct!

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.01.05.07.05: Explain what happens to the IAS and drag in the non-stable region if speed suddenly decreases and why this could occur. Looking at the figure above, we can see two distinct regions of the drag curve for speed stability. Below VMD the aircraft is speed unstable, whereas above VMD the aircraft is speed stable. Speed stability simply means a disturbance to the sped will return back to the equilibrium, whilst speed instability is the opposite. As the aircraft is situated in the speed unstable region, a sudden decrease in speed will cause the total drag to increase, whilst the thrust remains the same. A thrust deficit will be created. key_points: Note: This question appears to have different answers with different authorities
We think that the question has no correct answer in its current form

Please send us any exam feedback you have about this question so we can get it as representative as possible of the question in the exam quickly, thank you! As far as we currently know, the following authorities are considering the following options to be correct
learning.explanation: Note: This question appears to have different answers with different authorities. We think that the question has no correct answer in its current form. Please send us any exam feedback you have about this question so we can get it as representative as possible of the question in the exam quickly, thank you! As far as we currently know, the following authorities are considering the following options to be correct. Authority Reported Answer Latvia C (maintained its direction.) Poland Not C Austro Not C Spain A (greater than 10°.) Portugal A (greater than 10°.) We would say if your country is "Not C", go for A "greater than 10 degrees". A wing creates a force from the air flowing over it, and the direction and magnitude of that "resultant force" change based on the speed of the airflow, density of the air, and angle of attack (AoA) of the wing. This resultant force is split into two forces we know very well. Lift and Drag. Lift is the component of the resultant force that acts at 90º to the relative airflow (dictated by the speed and direction of the air approaching the wing - not yet affected by the presence of the wing or the aircraft), whereas drag is the force parallel to the relative airflow. This is the basics of "2D airflow", but gets a bit more complicated when we include "3D airflow", the existence of induced drag, wingtip vortices, etc. When flying at higher angles of attack, the effects of wingtip vortices introduce upwash ahead of the wing and downwash behind it, and this changes the "effective" angle of attack, which is the angle of air as it hits the wing, and is approaching from higher up than the relative airflow. The "effective lift vector" is at 90º to this "effective" angle of attack. Because this "effective" lift vector points slightly backwards, some of this "effective lift" is turned into drag. We call that "induced drag". The angle of "tilt" of the effective lift vector is the same angle that our angle of attack changes by (from actual AoA to effective AoA), and this angle of attack that we "lose" is called the induced angle of attack. This is particularly useful knowledge for questions about ground effect. Now to look at this question. When the aircraft slows down and increases its angle of attack to remain straight and level, the actual lift vector (90º to the relative airflow - so directly upwards) must stay the same direction and magnitude, to counteract the weight of the aircraft. The increase in AoA causes an increase in the strength of the wingtip vortices, and therefore the upwash ahead of the wing, thus increasing the induced AoA (the angle of attack that is lost). This means that the "effective lift vector" of the wings tilts back somewhat and increases in magnitude (to keep the actual lift constant), creating more induced drag. This "angle of tilt" (the induced AoA) is much less than the change in total AoA of 10º. Using normal wings, it would be in the region of 3º change. Therefore, the "effective lift vector" would tilt back by around 3º (less than 10º) and increase in magnitude, due to the larger induced AoA. Now that actually doesn't leave us with a correct answer. That is because none of the answers are correct. Even with a question that can be interpreted 2 ways, there is still no correct answer. If you take the question as literally as possible, then the actual lift vector (vertical) does not change in direction or magnitude, remaining vertical and equal to the weight force (option D is therefore wrong due to the magnitude). If you take the question to mean the "effective lift vector", then the correct answer would be "changed direction by a value smaller than 10°, with the lift vector pointing more rearwards because of a larger induced AOA.". None of the other answers fit this. Answer C says that it stays in the same direction with relation to the chord line, meaning that the effective lift vector moves by 10°, the same as the AoA change, which is not correct.

content.question: What type of drag is increased when an aerofoil is contaminated by dust and other particles?

options.A: Material drag
options.B: Induced drag
options.C: Wave drag
options.D: Friction drag

key_points: Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation, and Induced Drag - the result of lift generation
PARASITE DRAG is simply caused by the aircraft's shape, construction-type, and material
For instance, an airplane with a rough surface creates more parasite drag than one with a smooth surface
learning.explanation: Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation, and Induced Drag - the result of lift generation. PARASITE DRAG is simply caused by the aircraft's shape, construction-type, and material. For instance, an airplane with a rough surface creates more parasite drag than one with a smooth surface. And there are three basic types of parasite drag: 1. Skin Friction Drag is the result of the aircraft's surface being rough. Olympic swimmers wear swim caps on their heads, so hair doesn't create extra drag and they can swim faster through the water => this same principle can be applied to most aircraft, where a smooth skin reduces skin friction drag, improving performance and fuel efficiency. 2. Form Drag is the result of an object's general shape in relation to the relative wind. Resulting from the pressure at the leading edge of a body being greater than the pressure at the trailing edge. 3. Interference Drag is generated by the mixing of airflow streamlines between airframe components such as the wing and the fuselage or the landing gear strut and the fuselage. As air flows around different aircraft components and mixes, a localized shock wave is formed, creating a drag sum greater than the drag that components would have by themselves. Factors Affecting Parasite Drag: Indicated Airspeed - It varies directly with the square of the Indicated Airspeed. If IAS is doubled, the Parasite Drag will be four times greater - if IAS is halved, the Parasite Drag will be one quarter of its previous value. Configuration - Parasite Drag varies directly in proportion to the frontal area presented to the airflow. If flaps are deployed, the undercarriage lowered, speed brakes selected or roll control spoilers operated, "Parasite Area" is increased and Parasite Drag will increase. Airframe Contamination - Contamination by ice, frost, snow, mud, dust or slush will increase the Parasite Drag Coefficient, and in the case of severe airframe icing, the Parasite Area.

content.question:
Assuming no flow separation, which of these statements about the flow around an aerofoil as the angle of attack increases are correct or incorrect?
I. The stagnation point moves down.
II. The point of lowest static pressure moves forward.

options.A: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.B: I is correct, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: In aerodynamics, the stagnation point marks the spot in a flow field where the local velocity of the fluid (in our case, the atmosphere) reaches zero
This point typically lies on the leading edge of the wing
When viewed from the side, air above the stagnation point ascends while air below it descends
learning.explanation: In aerodynamics, the stagnation point marks the spot in a flow field where the local velocity of the fluid (in our case, the atmosphere) reaches zero. This point typically lies on the leading edge of the wing. When viewed from the side, air above the stagnation point ascends while air below it descends. Increasing the angle of attack causes the stagnation point to shift downward, leading to more air moving upward over the upper side of the wing and advancing the location of the lowest static pressure point. Consequently, at a specific angle of attack, this airflow triggers the stall warning, emitting an audible alert in the cockpit. The lowest pressure point resides along the upper surface of the wing and shifts in tandem with the Center of Pressure (CP) in response to changes in the Angle of Attack (AoA): an increase in AoA moves the CP forward, while a decrease moves it aft.

content.question: In straight and level flight, which sentence is correct regarding the CL/CD ratio?

options.A: It depends on the angle of attack.
options.B: The CL is higher than CD.
options.C: The CD is higher than CL.
options.D: CL equals CD.

key_points: The Lift to Drag ratio (CL/CD) is a measure of how much lift an aircraft produces per unit of drag
So an aircraft with a Lift to Drag ratio of 10/1 is producing 10 times more lift than it is producing drag
The lift to drag ratio depends on the angle of attack
learning.explanation: The Lift to Drag ratio (CL/CD) is a measure of how much lift an aircraft produces per unit of drag. So an aircraft with a Lift to Drag ratio of 10/1 is producing 10 times more lift than it is producing drag. The lift to drag ratio depends on the angle of attack. The angle of attack of a clean wing decides its lift coefficient, and its drag coefficient, then you can compare those two to get the lift/drag ratio. In reality, the lift is often much higher than the drag, so the L/D ratio is usually over 1. If an aircraft could fly fast enough to run at a very low (or negative) angle of attack, then its lift produced (which will equal its weight in straight and level flight) could be less than the drag (and therefore thrust - if the aircraft is at a constant speed). It is a bit of a crazy notion for civilian pilots, as the aircraft would have to have a higher thrust than its own weight, but this is quite common in fighter jets, especially modern jets or VTOL jets. We can see that by the fact that they can accelerate vertically upwards.

content.question: Decreasing the aspect ratio of a wing:

options.A: increases induced drag.
options.B: decreases stall speed.
options.C: increases gust load.

key_points: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag
This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient
If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag. This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient. If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices. Another factor increasing wing tip vortices is the aspect ratio (λ) of the wing. This is the ratio of the wing span to its mean chord. The aspect ratio of the wing is equal to the square of the wingspan divided by the wing surface area. Therefore a short but wide wing has a low aspect ratio but a long, narrow wing has a high aspect ratio. With a lower aspect ratio, the induced drag is higher, thus increasing wing tip vortices. With a high aspect ratio, the induced drag is lower, reducing wing tip vortices. We can therefore state that the relationship between wing tip vortices and aspect ratio is inversely proportional.

content.question: An aircraft has been parked outside overnight, in freezing conditions. The crew decides to depart WITHOUT having the airframe de-iced/anti-iced. What could be the principal danger during take-off?

options.A: Loss of control due to frozen deposits on the wings, which reduce CLMAX.
options.B: A higher stall speed due to wing contamination and reduced drag.
options.C: Uncommanded roll due to frozen deposits on the wings, which increase CLMAX.
options.D: A lower stall speed due to wing contamination and increased drag.

key_points: Stalling angle of attack: as ice builds up, the aerodynamic efficiency of the wing and its ability to prevent separation of the airflow and therefore stall is highly reduced
Ice will lead to sooner separation, smaller stalling angle of attack, therefore causing a lower CLMAX
Stall speed: referring to the lift equation, and assuming all other factors stay the same, ice buildup decreases the CLMAX and increases the mass of the aircraft in flight
learning.explanation: Stalling angle of attack: as ice builds up, the aerodynamic efficiency of the wing and its ability to prevent separation of the airflow and therefore stall is highly reduced. Ice will lead to sooner separation, smaller stalling angle of attack, therefore causing a lower CLMAX. Stall speed: referring to the lift equation, and assuming all other factors stay the same, ice buildup decreases the CLMAX and increases the mass of the aircraft in flight. Firstly just by itself an increase in mass causes an increase in stall speed. Secondly, a smaller CLMAX means that a higher speed will have to be maintained in order to maintain the same lift. Therefore our stall speed will have increase due to ice accretion. Controllability: on top of the fact that an increase in weight will mean that any input in the control surfaces will lead to a slower reaction by the aircraft, icing can also get stuck between the control surfaces and or completely nullify their effect. For example, icing on the horizontal stabilizer will occur before the main wing, and seeing as the tail is normally producing a downwards force, a stall of the tail plane will lead to a drop of the nose of the aircraft and controllability over the longitudinal axis will have been completely lost. Therefore controllability will decrease in icing conditions. The ice changes the airfoil cross section and destroys lift, increases drag and raises the stalling speed.

The three leading edge devices shown in the annex are: Leading Edge Flaps - similar to trailing edge flaps, they increase the camber f the wing to increase CL and CLMAX Kreuger Flaps - part of the lower surface of the leading edge, which can be rotated about its forward edge to force more airflow over the top of the wing at high angles of attack. content.question: Drag is in the direction of – and lift is perpendicular to the:

options.A: chord line.
options.B: relative wind/airflow.
options.C: horizon.
options.D: longitudinal axis.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
It acts in the direction of the relative wind
Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed (with a rate of 1/V²) and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

The difference in lift will cause a rolling moment which must be opposed by the ailerons, and the difference in drag will cause a yawing moment which must be opposed by the rudder. Whether the controls will be adequate to maintain straight and level flight will depend on the degree of asymmetry and the control power available.

learning.explanation: When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences a 50% reduction of its total drag. This phenomenon is ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tail plane. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, also determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. Aircraft entering ground effect: Downwash decreases. The effective angle of attack increases. Increased lift during landing if the angle of attack remains constant. The induced angle of attack decreases. Induced drag decreases. Aircraft leaving ground effect: Downwash increases. The effective angle of attack decreases. Decreased lift during take-off if the angle of attack remains constant. The induced angle of attack increases. Induced drag increases. As seen in figure 2, when entering ground effect, for the same angle of attack, lift is increased. Thus, to maintain the same CL as when before entering ground effect, the angle of attack should be decreased in order to decrease CL.

Particularly for large commercial jet aircraft, the use of flaps and slats is essential to allow acceptable take-off distances and land with reasonable speeds. They are incredibly powerful, which causes a massive problem if the flaps operate differently from each other, which we call flap/slat asymmetry. This is possible for many reasons, but a common one is if a flap extension/retraction system jams, the two flap settings will become different from each other. key_points: SURFACE-FRICTION DRAG Surface-friction drag is that portion of parasite drag caused by a boundary layer of almost static air that adheres to the skin of the aeroplane
Air directly in contact with the surface of the aeroplane will be dragged along at a slightly lower speed than that of the aeroplane because of the inherent cohesion of the air

learning.explanation: SURFACE-FRICTION DRAG Surface-friction drag is that portion of parasite drag caused by a boundary layer of almost static air that adheres to the skin of the aeroplane. Air directly in contact with the surface of the aeroplane will be dragged along at a slightly lower speed than that of the aeroplane because of the inherent cohesion of the air. The air further away from the surface of the aeroplane will be pulled along but at a lower speed than the surface air. This dragging effect decreases with increasing depth of the layer of air until at a particular depth the movement of the aeroplane does not affect the air at all. The depth of the layer of air from the aeroplane surface to the depth at which the air is unaffected is the boundary layer. The value of surface-friction drag varies and is determined by: - the total surface area of the aeroplane; - the coefficient of the air viscosity; - the rate of change of flow speed over the depth of the boundary layer. FLOW TRANSITION The nearer the transition point is to the leading edge of an aerofoil the greater is the amount of surface friction. The location of the transition point from laminar flow to turbulent flow is dependent on four factors: - surface condition; - speed of flow; - size of the object; - adverse pressure gradient. SURFACE CONDITION The depth of the boundary layer, both laminar and turbulent, increase with distance from the leading edge of an aerofoil. A rough, dirty, wet, or ice-covered surface will increase the depth of this layer causing greater interference with the airflow over the aerofoil. Polishing the aerofoil surface minimises the effect of this type of drag.

Tapered wings are structurally very strong, as the wing root is a lot bigger, allowing for a stronger connection to the fuselage, and the wing gradually gets thinner towards the wingtip where less reinforcement is required
learning.explanation: A tapered wing means that the wing chord line gets shorter going from root to tip. The chord of the wing is long at the root but shorter at the tip. Tapered wings are structurally very strong, as the wing root is a lot bigger, allowing for a stronger connection to the fuselage, and the wing gradually gets thinner towards the wingtip where less reinforcement is required. There are some aerodynamic benefits to tapered wings as well, which includes a small reduction in induced drag, due to the majority of the lift coming from the wing closer to the root. One of the problems with a tapered wing is the stall handling. On a rectangular wing, the stall begins at the back near the root, whereas on a tapered wing, the stall will begin near the tip instead, which leads to the aileron area becoming stalled, and losing aileron (roll) control (see first annex above). The taper of a wing is measured by the taper ratio, which is simply Taper ratio = tip chord / root chord So if the taper ratio is 0.5, the wingtip is half as wide as the root. Any number less than 1 indicates that the wing is tapered. 1 means the chord stays the same along the whole wingspan, more than 1 would be a wing that gets wider.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
It acts in the direction of the relative wind
Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed (with a rate of 1/V²) and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

learning.explanation: The CL of an aerofoil increases with angle of attack up to a maximum (CLMAX). Any further increase above this stalling angle, or critical angle of attack, will make it impossible for the airflow to smoothly follow the upper wing contour, and the flow will separate from the surface, causing CL to decrease and drag to increase rapidly. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. The formation of ice along a wing's leading edge greatly alters its aerodynamic contour and leads to premature separation of the boundary layer. This reduces the wing's stalling angle of attack and also its maximum coefficient of lift by up to 50% The increase in stall speed due to ice formation is not easy to quantify, as the accumulation and shape of the ice formation is impossible to predict. Ice or frost must never be allowed to remain on any aerodynamic surfaces in flight, nor must ice, frost, snow or other contamination be allowed to remain on the aircraft immediately before flight.

key_points: Terminology definition angle of attack: angle between the chord line and the relative (undisturbed) air flow
Local airflow = downwash at the trailing edge of the airfoil for example

Angle of attack (AOA, α - Greek letter alpha) is a term used in aerodynamics to describe the angle between the chord line of an airfoil and the vector representing the relative motion between the airfoil and the air through which it is moving
learning.explanation: Terminology definition angle of attack: angle between the chord line and the relative (undisturbed) air flow. Local airflow = downwash at the trailing edge of the airfoil for example. Angle of attack (AOA, α - Greek letter alpha) is a term used in aerodynamics to describe the angle between the chord line of an airfoil and the vector representing the relative motion between the airfoil and the air through which it is moving. For a two-dimensional airfoil, angle of attack is the angle between the chord line and the direction of arrival of the incoming air. In aviation, angle of attack is used to describe the angle between the chord line of the (three dimensional) wing of a fixed-wing aircraft and the vector representing the relative motion between the aircraft and the atmosphere. Since a wing can have twist, a chord line of the whole wing may not be definable, so an alternate reference line is simply defined. Often, the chord line of the root of the wing is chosen as the reference line. The angle of attack is often confused with the pitch angle of an aircraft and the angle of incidence. Pitch angle and angle of incidence are measured from the same reference line as angle of attack (conceptually the chord line), but pitch refers to the horizon and angle of incidence to the longitudinal axis of the aeroplane. Whereas, the angle of attack is measured from the (same) reference line to the direction of the arrival of the air to the wing (caused by the relative motion between the wing and the atmosphere). Note: Some tricky questions ask about the angle of attack of the aeroplane (not the wing) => angle between speed vector and longitudinal axis.

It is created by the vortices at the tip of an aircraft's wing. The magnitude of induced drag depends on the amount of lift being generated by the wing and on the shape and size of the wing. Induced drag can be reduced by: Using a high aspect ratio wing planform => Wings with high aspect ratio have lower induced drag than wings with low aspect ratio for the same wing area. So wings with a long span and a short chord have lower induced drag than wings with a short span and a long chord. key_points: Ground effect occurs when the surface interferes with the tip vortices and the downwash sheet

This effect becomes noticeable when the aircraft's height above the surface is equal to or less than its wingspan
learning.explanation: Ground effect occurs when the surface interferes with the tip vortices and the downwash sheet. Tip vortices generate drag and enhance downwash, but when ground effect is in play, drag is reduced for a given amount of lift, or lift is increased for the same angle of attack. This effect becomes noticeable when the aircraft's height above the surface is equal to or less than its wingspan. The closer the wing is to the surface, the stronger the ground effect. As a result, low-wing and low-tail aircraft experience a much more pronounced ground effect compared to high-wing designs. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences a 50% reduction of its total drag.

learning.explanation: Sweep Angle: The angle between the line of 25% chords and a perpendicular to the root chord. Purpose of Sweepback: To increase MCRIT. Sweepback factsheet: A Swept Wing Increases the Critical Mach Number (MCRIT). All other effects from a swept wing are by-products, most of them disadvantages. However, the benefits from a higher MCRIT outweigh the associated disadvantages. Increased tendency to stall at the tip first: Tip stall can lead to pitch-up, a major disadvantage. Pitch-up can give the tendency for a swept wing aircraft to Super Stall. Aircraft that show a significant tendency to pitch-up at the stall must be fitted with a stall prevention device, a stick pusher. When compared to a straight wing of the same section, a swept wing is less aerodynamically efficient. At a given angle of attack CL is less, which increases the stall speed. CLMAX is less and occurs at a higher angle of attack. The lift curve has a smaller gradient (change in CL per degree change in alpha is less). Swept wings must be fitted with complex high lift devices, both leading and trailing edge, to give a reasonable take-off and landing distance. A swept wing must be flown at a higher angle of attack than a straight wing to give the required lift coefficient; this is most noticeable at low speeds. A swept wing makes a small positive contribution to static directional stability. A swept wing makes a significant positive contribution to static lateral stability. At speeds higher than MCRIT a swept wing generates a nose-down pitching moment, a phenomenon known as Tuck Under. content.question: A supercritical wing:

options.A: will be free of Mach buffet in the transonic range.
options.B: will develop no transonic flow just above MCRIT.

key_points: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i
e
wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT
learning.explanation: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i.e. wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT. It increases the cruise Mach number, the range, and the endurance of the airplane. The main features of a supercritical wing are: The upper surface is flattened but the lower surface is reflex cambered towards the trailing edge. Thus, the airflow over the upper surface is not accelerated as much as conventional airfoils, which delays the formation of the shockwave to a higher speed. Compared with a conventional airfoil section it has a larger leading-edge radius, a flatter upper surface and both positive and negative camber and enables a relatively thick wing to be used for approximately the same cruise Mach number. The curved lower surface increases the lift generated by the aft end of the airfoil and replaces some of the lift lost from the flat upper surface. Because of the rear-loaded lift generation it is often called an aft-loaded wing. The leading edge of the supercritical wing has a greater radius than traditional airfoils that suffer from excessive wave drag and the loss of longitudinal stability (tuck under). By ensuring that its profile is carefully designed any expansion waves will be reflected from the subsonic boundary back to the shockwave, thereby weakening its intensity.

content.question: To reduce friction drag, some aeroplanes are equipped with modified wing designs to:

key_points: Friction drag represents the energy dissipated due to friction within the boundary layer
Within the boundary layer, the laminar layer is the thinnest and generates the least friction
However, as this laminar layer progresses toward the transition point, it transitions into the turbulent layer
learning.explanation: Friction drag represents the energy dissipated due to friction within the boundary layer. Within the boundary layer, the laminar layer is the thinnest and generates the least friction. However, as this laminar layer progresses toward the transition point, it transitions into the turbulent layer. This turbulent layer is thicker and contributes to higher friction drag. To enhance aerodynamic performance, certain aerofoils are engineered to delay this transition, allowing it to occur further downstream. This strategy increases the extent of laminar flow, reducing overall friction drag. For instance, vortex generators may be used to extend the laminar flow by energizing the boundary layer and creating turbulent flow, which does cause more drag indeed, but that's how separation is delayed which is actually more important when you look at the big picture. Vortex generators are located on the upper surface of a wing to create a slightly disturbed airflow perpendicular to the leading edge of the wing. The higher energy level delays the boundary layer separation (resulting in an extended laminar flow section), which reduces the stall speed.

learning.explanation: CRITICAL MACH NUMBER Critical Mach Number (MCRIT): The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft (usually the point of maximum thickness on the aerofoil) first reaches the speed of sound. content.question: What happens to the airflow’s static temperature (T), Mach number (M), and total pressure (Pt) when passing through a normal shock wave?

options.A: T decreases, M increases, Pt increases.
options.B: T decreases, M increases, Pt decreases.
options.C: T increases, M decreases, Pt increases.
options.D: T increases, M decreases, Pt decreases.

key_points: An airplane flying at low, subsonic, speeds causes air-pressure changes because of its movement but they are relatively small
It is convenient, therefore, to treat the air as though it could not be compressed
However, the air-pressure changes caused by the movement of an airplane at high speed, close to the speed of sound, are considerable and cannot be ignored
learning.explanation: An airplane flying at low, subsonic, speeds causes air-pressure changes because of its movement but they are relatively small. It is convenient, therefore, to treat the air as though it could not be compressed. However, the air-pressure changes caused by the movement of an airplane at high speed, close to the speed of sound, are considerable and cannot be ignored. The air is compressible and its effect on the airplane must be accounted for when it is travelling at high speed. An airplane moving through the air creates a pressure wave around it, which is propagated away from it in all directions simultaneously at the speed of sound. For an airplane flying at a relatively low speed, less than the speed of sound, the air-pressure wave ahead of the airplane can move away from the airplane. Consequently, air-pressure, air-density, air-temperature, and air-velocity changes take place ahead of the leading edge of the wings and are a gradual process. If, however, the airplane is travelling at the speed of sound then the air-pressure wave ahead of the airplane is unable to move away from the airplane and a wave of compressed air builds up at the leading edge of the wing. This compression wave will create a discontinuity plane, where the airstream experiences the following changes: Air Temperature - Increases (due to compression) Static Pressure - Increases (due to compression) Total Pressure - Decreases (Normal shockwave suffers greater loss than an oblique shockwave) Air Density - Increases (Oblique shockwave has less compression) LSS - Increases (due to the temperature increase) Speed of Airflow - Decreases to less than Mach 1 (normal shockwave). Decreases but still above Mach 1.0 (oblique shockwave). Minimum energy loss through a normal shock wave will occur when the Mach number of the airflow in front of the shock wave is small but supersonic.

content.question: Whilst flying at a constant IAS and at n = 1, as the aeroplane mass increases, the value of MCRIT:

options.A: increases.
options.B: remains constant.
options.C: is independent of the angle of attack.
options.D: decreases.

key_points: Critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the speed at which airflow around an aircraft reaches sonic speed (M = 1)
It represents the maximum speed where no part of the wing goes supersonic, especially where airflow accelerates most over the wing's upper surface
This acceleration is linked to the wing's curvature, or camber
learning.explanation: Critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the speed at which airflow around an aircraft reaches sonic speed (M = 1). It represents the maximum speed where no part of the wing goes supersonic, especially where airflow accelerates most over the wing's upper surface. This acceleration is linked to the wing's curvature, or camber. When the angle of attack (AoA) increases, airflow over the wing's upper surface speeds up even more. Thus, a higher angle of attack leads to a lower MCRIT because sonic speed is reached at a slower flying speed. Imagine two planes flying at the same constant speed at level flight (n = 1), one heavier than the other. The heavier plane needs increase its angle of attack to generate enough lift to stay up because it's heavier. As the angle of attack increases, the air above the heavier plane's wing speeds up more, even though both planes are flying at the same IAS. The heavier one would hit the speed of sound over its wings before the lighter one, even if they had the same IAS. This happens because the heavier plane needs to have a higher angle of attack to stay at the same speed, which means it's already pushing the air faster over its wings. Thus, owing to the increased angle of attack needed to sustain flight at a given IAS, the heavier aircraft demonstrates a lower MCRIT compared to the lighter one.

When supersonic airflow passes through a normal shock wave, how do the following conditions change?

key_points: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag
This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft
The speed of sound is defined as the rate at which small pressure disturbances are propagated through the air, which is solely a function of air temperature
learning.explanation: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag. This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft. The speed of sound is defined as the rate at which small pressure disturbances are propagated through the air, which is solely a function of air temperature. THE DEVELOPMENT OF SHOCK WAVES When aircraft fly through the air, every part of them sets up tiny pressure disturbances, which radiate outward at the speed of sound in all directions. As Mach number increases, the flow over the wing continues to accelerate and eventually reaches a sonic value at a particular point on the wing, normally the point of maximum thickness. With increasing Mach number, this point grows into an area of supersonic flow, so the air moving over the upper surface will be moving rearward faster than the pressure disturbances can move forward. These disturbances consequently pile up on each other and form a shock wave. The shock wave acts perpendicular, or normal, to the surface, and is more commonly referred to as a normal shock wave. Notably, this occurs where the flow changes from supersonic back to subsonic. The overall direction of the airflow remains the same, but as it passes through the shock wave, the following changes take place: - The flow is rapidly decelerated to a subsonic Mach number. - Static pressure increases. - Temperature increases. - Density increases. - The energy of the airstream (total pressure) is greatly reduced. As stated above, the Local Speed of Sound (LSS) is solely dependent on the Air Temperature. After the shockwave, the temperature increases and, therefore, the LSS also increases.

learning.explanation: Critical Mach Number: (MCRIT) The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft first reaches the speed of sound. At low subsonic speeds, the lift coefficient CL is assumed to be constant at a given angle of attack. With increasing Mach number, however, it will vary as At high altitude, a large high-speed jet transport aircraft will be cruising at a speed marginally above its critical Mach number, and it will have a small shock wave on the wing. If such an aircraft overspeeds, the shock wave will rapidly grow larger, causing the static pressure to increase sharply in the immediate vicinity of the shock wave. The locally increased adverse pressure gradient will cause the boundary layer to separate immediately behind the shock wave. This is called a ‘shock stall’ because it results from a separated boundary layer just as the low speed stall does. Shock stall occurs when the lift coefficient, as a function of Mach number, reaches its maximum value (for a given angle of attack).

B737 from Mach
learning.explanation: Mach trim is used to trim the aircraft at high Mach numbers (e.g. B737 from Mach.615). It prevents instability and tuck under (which appears above MCRIT) due to an increased pitch down moment, which is caused the following reasons: CP moves aft shock waves at the wing root reduced effectiveness of the tailplane Mach trim counteracts (increases pitch up) by one of the following: adjusting stabilizer adjusting elevator trim tank (fuel pumped to the tail) Outcome: stick force gradient will be maintained longitudinal stability will be increased tuck under will be avoided Mach Trim System relates to the pitch channel of the Auto Flight Control System (AFCS). It is designed as an AFCS sub-system and is therefore, like the yaw damper, operational irrespective of whether or not the AFCS is active (autopilot engaged or disengaged). The heart of the Mach trim system is the coupler unit. This receives signals, corresponding to Mach number, from the Air Data Computer (ADC). Whenever these signals exceed the pre-set value (for the aeroplane type) the trim coupler unit releases the brake and the speed signal from the ADC is fed to the motor. This causes the stabiliser to move in such a way that the elevators are driven upward, counteracting any tendency to a "Mach Tuck-under". Internal monitoring of the system provides a failure warning in the form of the illumination of a fail indicator light. Although connected to the pitch channel the system is totally independent of the pitch control channel of the AFCS. In other words, the Mach trim system provides speed stability at higher Mach numbers. It operates (adjusts the elevators with respect to the stabilizer as speed increases) only above certain minimum Mach number - for example on a B737-300 it is above Mach 0.615. With the Mach trim system INOP the maximum speed of the aircraft is typically limited to a lower Mach number than normally. "Tuck-under" is the phenomena encountered by aeroplanes flying at high subsonic, transonic or supersonic speeds. In these speed regimes there is typically a significant rearward movement of the Centre of Pressure (CP). In order to prevent this becoming an uncontrollable "nose-down" pitching motion, it is necessary to provide some form of compensation. This is done by the use of a Mach Trim System. Or otherwise said the Mach trim system allows to increase the longitudinal static stability of the aircraft by changing the horizontal stabilizer according to the Mach number.

learning.explanation: Tuck under, or Mach tuck, is an effect where the aircraft tends to pitch downward as the airflow around the airfoil reaches supersonic speeds. It occurs well before reaching Mach 1 speed. Mach tuck can be caused by two things; a rearward movement of the center op pressure (CP) and a decrease in wing downwash at the tailplane. Both of these conditions cause a pitch down effect, as they generate a (bigger) positive moment aft of the CG. When the airflow around the airfoil starts reaching supersonic speed (this can happen before the aircraft flies at Mach 1 speed), small shockwave forms over the upper side of the wing, generating a large amount of lift. If speed increases, this shockwave will move backwards to the mid chord position, causing the CP to move backwards. The adjusted flow over the wings can reduce downwash on the tailplane, contributing to Mach tuck.

If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer

learning.explanation: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back. If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer. This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation. The normal tip vortice on a swept wing joins up with a leading edge separation bubble, creating a larger vortex called the Ram’s horn vortex. This vortex goes inboard along the wing’s leading edge. The downward flow from the vortex induces pressure on the boundary layer at the wingtip, whereas on straight wings the exact opposite occurs. With a swept wing, this creates a slow-moving layer of air at the wing tip. This slow-moving air will separate into disturbed flow and will then stall the tip. As the wingtips for a swept wing are positioned aft of the center of pressure (CP), the center of pressure upon a wing tip stall will move forward, creating a nose up moment. This nose up moment will further increase the Angle of Attack if not corrected in time, increasing the layer of slow-moving air, worsening the situation. The pitch up phenomenon is a dangerous characteristic of swept wing aircraft that move at high speed. It could result in a quickly worsening stalling situation, making it very hard to recover.

This requirement is so important that once satisfied, the supersonic configuration usually has sufficient longitudinal control power for all other conditions of flight. key_points: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1 / 2 ρ V2

Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes

learning.explanation: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1 / 2 ρ V2. Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes. If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes. At a constant EAS, Mach number will increase as altitude increases. Figure 1 shows the variation of stalling speed with altitude at constant load factor (n). Such a curve is called the stalling boundary for the given load factor, in which altitude is plotted against equivalent airspeed. At this load factor (1g), the aircraft cannot fly at speeds to the left of this boundary. Over the lower range of altitude, stall speed does not vary with altitude. This is because at these low altitudes, the Mach number at VS is too low for compressibility effects to be present. Eventually (approximately 30000 ft), Mach number at VS has increased with altitude to such an extent that these effects are important, and the rise in stalling speed with altitude is apparent. As altitude increases, stall speed is initially constant then increases, due to compressibility.

options.B: be situated at the greatest wing thickness when the aeroplane reaches the speed of sound.

key_points: An airplane does not have to be flying at the local speed of sound for the airflow over the wings to be supersonic
A normal shockwave can develop at any time the airplane is in the transonic speed range
The function of the wing is to accelerate the air passing over its upper surface
learning.explanation: An airplane does not have to be flying at the local speed of sound for the airflow over the wings to be supersonic. A normal shockwave can develop at any time the airplane is in the transonic speed range. The function of the wing is to accelerate the air passing over its upper surface. The airflow may be subsonic at the leading edge of the wing but can be accelerated to become supersonic by the trailing edge of the wing, despite the fact that the airplane is flying at a speed of less than Mach 1.0. This is transonic flight, which usually occurs between Mach 0.75 and Mach 1.2. At speeds less than Mach 0.75 all the airflow over the wing is subsonic and as the airplane accelerates the first shockwave will form on the upper surface at the wing root. When the air over the upper surface of the wing becomes sonic, a shockwave forms because the pressure waves over the rear of wing at the wing root are attempting to move forward and meet the air moving aft from the leading edge at exactly the same speed but in the opposite direction. The meeting point is usually just aft of the point of maximum camber because this is where the air over the upper surface of the wing is accelerating at the greatest rate. The meeting point of the two air-pressure waves is the shockwave and is where the airflow changes from being sonic or supersonic to become subsonic. Air passing through the shockwave experiences an increase of pressure, temperature, and density. If the airplane speed continues to increase the area of supersonic air on top of the wing spreads backward towards the trailing edge, resulting in the shockwave moving aft. Thicker wing with a large amount of camber has a lower critical Mach number than a thin wing with little camber because the airflow over its upper surface accelerates to a higher speed than it would over a thin wing. Deflecting a control surface upward decreases camber, this will arrest the aft movement of the shockwave (or, in fact, move it slightly forward) due to the increase in MCRIT.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.05.01.05: Describe the following limiting speeds for descent: maximum operating speed (VMO); maximum Mach number (MMO). Aircraft certified under CS-25 (and some aircraft under CS-23) are given maximum flight speeds as a VMO and MMO (maximum operating airspeed/Mach No.). Depending on the altitude and air temperature, one of these will correspond to a lower airspeed than the other. That one will be the most limiting. The MMO is most limiting at high altitudes, which is when it is most useful for us to refer to our speed in Mach No., whereas at lower altitudes, the VMO is most limiting, and we should use IAS/CAS instead. The point where this crossover happens is called the crossover altitude. A common altitude for this is around 28000 ft, but it depends on the aircraft and conditions. If descending at a constant mach number, the Mach number will not exceed the MMO (as it is constant), but using the ECTM graph above, we can see that the IAS will be increasing, and therefore the IAS may well reach and exceed VMO if the crossover is delayed to a lower altitude. The other two options "shock stall speed" and "never exceed speed" can be discounted here, as aircraft with VMO/MMO do not have a VNE and the shock stall speed occurs based on the Mach No. and MMO, both of which we know remain constant (and it is not a limiting speed as such).

content.question: What happens to the strength, the length, and the location of a normal shock wave when the Mach number (M) is increasing at positive lift? The strength of the shock wave...

key_points: An airplane does not have to be flying at the local speed of sound for the airflow over the wings to be supersonic
A normal shockwave can develop at any time the airplane is in the transonic speed range
The function of the wing is to accelerate the air passing over its upper surface
learning.explanation: An airplane does not have to be flying at the local speed of sound for the airflow over the wings to be supersonic. A normal shockwave can develop at any time the airplane is in the transonic speed range. The function of the wing is to accelerate the air passing over its upper surface. The airflow may be subsonic at the leading edge of the wing but can be accelerated to become supersonic by the trailing edge of the wing, despite the fact that the airplane is flying at a speed of less than Mach 1.0. This is transonic flight, which usually occurs between Mach 0.75 and Mach 1.2. At speeds less than Mach 0.75 all the airflow over the wing is subsonic and as the airplane accelerates the first shockwave will form on the upper surface at the wing root. When the air over the upper surface of the wing becomes sonic, a shockwave forms because the pressure waves over the rear of wing at the wing root are attempting to move forward and meet the air moving aft from the leading edge at exactly the same speed but in the opposite direction. The meeting point is usually just aft of the point of maximum camber because this is where the air over the upper surface of the wing is accelerating at the greatest rate. The meeting point of the two air-pressure waves is the shockwave and is where the airflow changes from being sonic or supersonic to become subsonic. Air passing through the shockwave experiences an increase of pressure, temperature, and density. If the airplane speed continues to increase the area of supersonic air on top of the wing spreads backward towards the trailing edge, resulting in the shockwave moving aft.

content.question: Vortex generators on the upper side of the wing surface will:

options.A: increase the magnitude of the shock wave.
options.B: decrease the span wise flow at high Mach numbers.
