key_points: The unfavorable characteristics associated with compressibility are due to boundary layer separation behind the shock wave (shock stall)
Flow separation occurs because the boundary layer loses kinetic energy as it flows against the adverse pressure gradient
Shock wave formation increases the adverse pressure gradient so the loss of kinetic energy in the boundary layer will be greater
learning.explanation: The unfavorable characteristics associated with compressibility are due to boundary layer separation behind the shock wave (shock stall). Flow separation occurs because the boundary layer loses kinetic energy as it flows against the adverse pressure gradient. Shock wave formation increases the adverse pressure gradient so the loss of kinetic energy in the boundary layer will be greater. Increasing the kinetic energy of the boundary layer will reduce flow separation. Simple devices called vortex generators are used to re-energize the boundary layer. Vortex generators are small plates, vanes, blades, or wedges mounted in spanwise rows along the wing surface. Each vortex generator produces a vortex at its tip which will induce high energy air from the free stream flow to mix with the boundary layer, thus increasing its kinetic energy and helping it flow through the shock wave with much less separation. Vortex generators are usually located on the upper wing surface, particularly ahead of control surfaces, but may be used anywhere where separation is causing high drag or reduced control effectiveness. It should be noted that vortex generators may also be used on subsonic aircraft to prevent separation caused by high adverse pressure gradients due to the contours of the surface.

content.question: Large jet aeroplanes are often made with supercritical aerofoils, rather than conventional aerofoils. Which of the following is one of the benefits of this, with regards to flying at speeds greater than MCRIT?

options.A: The aeroplane may fly at a greater Mach number and, initially, only experience a slight increase in drag.
options.B: Flying faster than MCRIT will NOT cause any shock waves around the profile until the aeroplane reaches Mach 1.0.
options.C: The aeroplane will have stronger, opposing shock waves that will cancel each other out and reduce drag.
options.D: Flying faster than MCRIT reduces the amount of wave drag as the shock waves are weaker than when flying below MCRIT.

key_points: When air travels over an aerofoil in normal operation, the air above the aerofoil, near the leading edge, increases in velocity, due to the "squashing" of the streamlines together, causing a venturi effect, creating the low pressure zone that is required
This means that air is usually going faster over the top of the wing than anywhere else on the airframe
As the aircraft approaches the speed of sound, Mach 1, the air above the wing will get there first, as it is faster than the freestream airflow (TAS)
learning.explanation: When air travels over an aerofoil in normal operation, the air above the aerofoil, near the leading edge, increases in velocity, due to the "squashing" of the streamlines together, causing a venturi effect, creating the low pressure zone that is required. This means that air is usually going faster over the top of the wing than anywhere else on the airframe. As the aircraft approaches the speed of sound, Mach 1, the air above the wing will get there first, as it is faster than the freestream airflow (TAS). In particular, it is usually the air just above the wing root, where the wing is thickest, and the streamlines get "squashed" the most, that is the first bit of air to reach the sound barrier. The TAS at which the first particle of air becomes sonic (exactly Mach 1) is called MCRIT, and is the beginning of the transonic speed regime. Above this speed, shockwaves will begin to form on various parts of the airframe. Above MCRIT, the air flowing over the top of the wing becomes supersonic, and at the point at which the air wants to decelerate back below Mach 1.0, a shockwave is formed. This shockwaves is a very thin surface where the characteristics of the air change dramatically, and can cause some airflow separation, leading to an effect called the shock stall. There are many ways to delay MCRIT and the shock stall, one of which is to fly with a supercritical wing. A supercritical aerofoil has a much flatter top surface, which not only increases MCRIT and MDD (drag divergence)* but also creates a weaker shockwave when one is formed, just above MCRIT. The shockwaves on a supercritical aerofoil quickly move to the trailing edge, making the shock stall a much smaller effect. For civilian applications, the main benefit is the faster speed that can be flown, before drag increases due to wave drag. The higher MCRIT/MDD and ability to fly just above MCRIT with little extra drag is very useful for long range jet aeroplanes, for extra range, speed and ability to fly at higher altitudes. *MDD (drag divergence Mach number) is a speed which comes just above MCRIT, where the drag begins to increase rapidly with increase in speed. This is what we really want to make higher, and using a supercritical aerofoil does exactly that.

content.question: One of the advantages of a supercritical aerofoil when compared with a conventional aerofoil is that..

options.A: it increases MCRIT.
options.B: it produces less trim drag.
options.C: it gives less negative pitching moments.
options.D: complex high lift devices can be omitted.

key_points: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i
e
wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT
learning.explanation: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i.e. wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT. It increases the cruise Mach number, the range, and the endurance of the airplane. The main features of a supercritical wing are: The upper surface is flattened but the lower surface is reflex cambered towards the trailing edge. Thus, the airflow over the upper surface is not accelerated as much as conventional airfoils, which delays the formation of the shockwave to a higher speed. Compared with a conventional airfoil section it has a larger leading-edge radius, a flatter upper surface and both positive and negative camber and enables a relatively thick wing to be used for approximately the same cruise Mach number. The curved lower surface increases the lift generated by the aft end of the airfoil and replaces some of the lift lost from the flat upper surface. Because of the rear-loaded lift generation it is often called an aft-loaded wing. In supersonic flight, the thickness ratio and leading edge radius must be small to decrease wave drag, which occurs due to the formation of shockwaves at certain critical points on the aircraft's surface. A thinner wing with a smaller leading edge radius will produce smaller shockwaves and thus less wave drag.

At high altitude, a large high-speed jet transport aircraft will be cruising at a speed marginally above its critical Mach number, and it will have a small shock wave on the wing

learning.explanation: Critical Mach Number: (MCRIT) The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft first reaches the speed of sound. At high altitude, a large high-speed jet transport aircraft will be cruising at a speed marginally above its critical Mach number, and it will have a small shock wave on the wing. If such an aircraft overspeeds, the shock wave will rapidly grow larger, causing the static pressure to increase sharply in the immediate vicinity of the shock wave. The locally increased adverse pressure gradient will cause the boundary layer to separate immediately behind the shock wave. This is called a ‘shock stall’ because it results from a separated boundary layer just as the low speed stall does. In the transonic range, the ‘shock stall’ is the separation of the boundary layer from the upper surface of the wing behind a shockwave. This causes the total lift generated to decrease. Unlike the normal high-incidence angle stall, the ‘shock stall’ occurs at low angles of attack and at an unexpectedly high IAS. For swept-wing airplanes because the wing-tips stall first the airplane has a nose-up pitch tendency. The angle of attack of the high-speed shock stall decreases as the Mach number increases and CLMAX decreases in a similar manner. Because the turbulent airflow behind a shockwave results in an increased loss of lift, any large rapid increase of speed can induce a premature stall.

When an aircraft accelerates through the transonic speed range and exceeds its Critical Mach number, the air flowing over the upper wing surface will accelerate above Mach 1 first, and to slow down below Mach 1 again, it creates a normal shock wave perpendicular the upper surface of the wing. key_points: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i
e
wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT
learning.explanation: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i.e. wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT. It increases the cruise Mach number, the range, and the endurance of the airplane. The main features of a supercritical wing are: The upper surface is flattened but the lower surface is reflex cambered towards the trailing edge. Thus, the airflow over the upper surface is not accelerated as much as conventional airfoils, which delays the formation of the shockwave to a higher speed. Compared with a conventional airfoil section it has a larger leading-edge radius, a flatter upper surface and both positive and negative camber and enables a relatively thick wing to be used for approximately the same cruise Mach number. The curved lower surface increases the lift generated by the aft end of the airfoil and replaces some of the lift lost from the flat upper surface. Because of the rear-loaded lift generation it is often called an aft-loaded wing. The leading edge of the supercritical wing has a greater radius than traditional airfoils that suffer from excessive wave drag and the loss of longitudinal stability (tuck under). By ensuring that its profile is carefully designed any expansion waves will be reflected from the subsonic boundary back to the shockwave, thereby weakening its intensity.

learning.explanation: The Earth's atmosphere is an extremely thin sheet of air extending from the surface of the Earth to the edge of space, about 60 miles above the surface of the Earth. The first two zones are the troposphere and the stratosphere. The troposphere runs from the surface of the Earth to 36,152 feet. In the troposphere, the temperature decreases linearly with altitude at a constant rate of -1,98°C/1000 ft. The lower portion of the stratosphere is an isothermal layer where the temperature remains constant (approximately -57°C) with increasing height, and then in its upper layers the temperature increases to around 0° C at the stratopause. For the study of high speed flight we are interested in the speed at which the infinitesimally small pressure disturbances (waves) travel through the atmosphere. Pressure waves ‘propagate’ from their source, that is, each air molecule is rapidly vibrated in turn and passes on the disturbance to its neighbour. The speed of propagation of small pressure waves depends upon the temperature of the air ONLY. The higher the temperature, the higher the speed of propagation. Therefore only possible answer can be LSS will decrease in the troposphere. Since temperature decreases with increasing altitude in the troposphere LSS would decrease with temperature as well.

key_points: The speed of sound (LSS) is the speed at which sound or pressure waves move through a gas, liquid, or solid
The speed of sound is proportional to the square root of the temperature; the speed of sound (LSS) will increase as the temperature increases
A higher SAT leads to a higher TAS
learning.explanation: The speed of sound (LSS) is the speed at which sound or pressure waves move through a gas, liquid, or solid. The speed of sound is proportional to the square root of the temperature; the speed of sound (LSS) will increase as the temperature increases. A higher SAT leads to a higher TAS. As the SAT increases, the air molecules become less dense, resulting in a higher TAS for a given CAS. Therefore, in the given scenario, where the temperature SAT increases from -35°C to -30°C, the TAS will also increase. The Mach number (M) is the ratio of the true airspeed (TAS) to the local speed of sound (LSS), and it’s a measure of compressibility. M = TAS / LSS In this scenario, both TAS and LSS increase, therefore Mach number remains constant, given that the CAS remains constant.

learning.explanation: The critical Mach number, or Mcrit, is the lowest Mach number at which the airflow over some point of the aircraft reaches the speed of sound (Mach 1), but does not exceed it. At the lower critical Mach number, the airflow around the entire aircraft is subsonic. At the higher critical Mach number, the airflow around the whole aircraft is supersonic. Because of the critical Mach number, it is possible that shockwaves can occur at speeds even below Mach 1. As the aircraft speeds up beyond this critical Mach number, drag increases dramatically. This means that air is usually going faster over the top of the wing than anywhere else on the airframe

learning.explanation: When air travels over an aerofoil in normal operation, the air above the aerofoil, near the leading edge, increases in velocity, due to the "squashing" of the streamlines together, causing a venturi effect, creating the low pressure zone that is required as part of creating lift. This means that air is usually going faster over the top of the wing than anywhere else on the airframe. As an aircraft approaches the speed of sound, Mach 1, the air above the wing will get there first, as it is faster than the freestream airflow (TAS). In particular, it is usually the air just above the wing root, where the wing is thickest, and the streamlines get "squashed" the most, that is the first bit of air to reach the sound barrier. The TAS at which the first particle of air becomes sonic (exactly Mach 1) is called MCRIT, and is the beginning of the transonic speed regime. Above this speed, shockwaves will begin to form on various parts of the airframe. MCRIT is variable, and in particular depends on the airspeed increase over the wing. If the speed increase equates to M0.2, for instance, then the aircraft will have an MCRIT of M0.8, a higher MCRIT than if the speed increase due to the wing was M0.25, giving an MCRIT of M0.75. A higher MCRIT is better, as the drag increases rapidly just above the MCRIT, at MDD, the drag divergence speed, and we would like to fly as fast as possible with the lowest drag. A large factor of the MCRIT is the thickness of the aerofoil, as thicker aerofoils "squash" the air above the wing more, thereby speeding it up more. Therefore, thinner aerofoils are more suited to high speed flight, as they have a higher MCRIT, and also handle the transonic speed regime better in general. For this question, then, thicker aerofoils decrease the MCRIT (which is bad), and thinner aerofoils increase MCRIT (good).

content.question: When air has passed through a shock wave the local speed of sound is:

options.A: increased.
options.B: not affected.
options.C: decreased and beyond a certain Mach number start increasing again.
options.D: decreased.

key_points: An airplane flying at low, subsonic, speeds causes air-pressure changes because of its movement but they are relatively small
It is convenient, therefore, to treat the air as though it could not be compressed
However, the air-pressure changes caused by the movement of an airplane at high speed, close to the speed of sound, are considerable and cannot be ignored
learning.explanation: An airplane flying at low, subsonic, speeds causes air-pressure changes because of its movement but they are relatively small. It is convenient, therefore, to treat the air as though it could not be compressed. However, the air-pressure changes caused by the movement of an airplane at high speed, close to the speed of sound, are considerable and cannot be ignored. The air is compressible and its effect on the airplane must be accounted for when it is travelling at high speed. An airplane moving through the air creates a pressure wave around it, which is propagated away from it in all directions simultaneously at the speed of sound. For an airplane flying at a relatively low speed, less than the speed of sound, the air-pressure wave ahead of the airplane can move away from the airplane. Consequently, air-pressure, air-density, air-temperature, and air-velocity changes take place ahead of the leading edge of the wings and are a gradual process. If, however, the airplane is travelling at the speed of sound then the air-pressure wave ahead of the airplane is unable to move away from the airplane and a wave of compressed air builds up at the leading edge of the wing. This compression wave will create a discontinuity plane, where the airstream experiences the following changes: Air Temperature - Increases (due to compression) Static Pressure - Increases (due to compression) Total Pressure - Decreases (Normal shockwave suffers greater loss than an oblique shockwave) Air Density - Increases (Oblique shockwave has less compression) LSS - Increases (due to the temperature increase) Speed of Airflow - Decreases to less than Mach 1 (normal shockwave). Decreases but still above Mach 1.0 (oblique shockwave). Minimum energy loss through a normal shock wave will occur when the Mach number of the airflow in front of the shock wave is small but supersonic. key_points: EFFECTS OF SHOCKWAVE FORMATION The formation and development of shock waves on the wing have effects on lift, drag, stability and control
Many of these effects are caused by shock induced separation
As the air flows through the shock wave, the sudden rise in pressure causes the boundary layer to thicken and often to separate
learning.explanation: EFFECTS OF SHOCKWAVE FORMATION The formation and development of shock waves on the wing have effects on lift, drag, stability and control. Many of these effects are caused by shock induced separation. As the air flows through the shock wave, the sudden rise in pressure causes the boundary layer to thicken and often to separate. This increases the depth of the turbulent wake behind the wing. FLYING CONTROLS The deflection of a conventional hinged-flap type of control creates a force ahead of the control surface that is normally greater than that which the control surface itself produces. When there is a shockwave established on the lifting surface ahead of the control surface this is no longer the case because pressure variations cannot be transmitted forward through the shockwave. The shockwave moves slightly aft when an aileron is deflected downwards. This effectively diminishes the result of deflecting the control surface because only the airflow passing over the control surface is modified. This effect is exacerbated when the shockwave reaches the trailing edge of the aerofoil and the control effectiveness is decreased even further. In transonic flight the ailerons are less effective than in subsonic flight because aileron deflection only partially affects the pressure distribution around the wing. These characteristics have led to the substitution of the tailplane and elevator combination in high-speed aeroplanes with a fully flying horizontal stabiliser. On these aeroplanes the conventional wing-tip ailerons are replaced with differential spoilers and/or inboard ailerons that are for use when the aeroplane is flying at transonic speeds. Because of the increased input forces required from the pilot during flight at transonic speeds and the large variation of the stick forces encountered during the transition of the shockwave over the control surface, most high-speed aeroplanes are fitted with fully power-operated controls.

key_points: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag
This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft
The speed of sound is defined as the rate at which small pressure disturbances are propagated through the air, which is solely a function of air temperature
learning.explanation: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag. This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft. The speed of sound is defined as the rate at which small pressure disturbances are propagated through the air, which is solely a function of air temperature. THE DEVELOPMENT OF SHOCK WAVES When aircraft fly through the air, every part of them sets up tiny pressure disturbances, which radiate outward at the speed of sound in all directions. As Mach number increases, the flow over the wing continues to accelerate and eventually reaches a sonic value at a particular point on the wing, normally the point of maximum thickness. With increasing Mach number, this point grows into an area of supersonic flow, so the air moving over the upper surface will be moving rearward faster than the pressure disturbances can move forward. These disturbances consequently pile up on each other and form a shock wave. The shock wave acts perpendicular (90 degrees), or normal, to the surface, and is more commonly referred to as a normal shock wave. Notably, this occurs where the flow changes from supersonic back to subsonic. The overall direction of the airflow remains the same, but as it passes through the shock wave, the following changes take place: - The flow is rapidly decelerated to a subsonic Mach number. - Static pressure increases. - Temperature increases. - Density increases. - The energy of the airstream (total pressure) is greatly reduced.

options.B: The total pressure will Increase as shock waves start forming In areas where there is significant local acceleration, causing wave drag.

Please let us know if you come across this question in your examination. Thank you! As an aircraft accelerates to high speeds, it enters a regime where the effects of compressibility become significant. The critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the airspeed at which the local airflow over certain parts of the aircraft (typically near the wing's leading edge or other protuberances) reaches the speed of sound (Mach 1). The airflow over the aircraft's surfaces starts to approach or reach the speed of sound. This means that some parts of the aircraft may experience local airflow velocities at or near Mach 1. This increased compressibility is what leads to changes in the behavior of the airflow. As the airflow reaches or exceeds Mach 1 locally, shock waves can start to form. These are sudden, discontinuous changes in air pressure and density. Shock waves can form on the wings, fuselage, and other parts of the aircraft that have particular shapes or characteristics that cause local acceleration of the airflow. One of the consequences of compressibility effects is that the total pressure of the airflow increases. This increase in total pressure can lead to an artificially high reading on instruments like the airspeed indicator. CAS measures the pressure differential between the pitot tube (which senses ram air pressure) and static pressure. At high speeds, the ram air pressure component becomes significant, causing CAS to read higher than TAS.

key_points: An airplane does not have to be flying at the local speed of sound for the airflow over the wings to be supersonic
A normal shockwave can develop at any time the airplane is in the transonic speed range
The function of the wing is to accelerate the air passing over its upper surface
learning.explanation: An airplane does not have to be flying at the local speed of sound for the airflow over the wings to be supersonic. A normal shockwave can develop at any time the airplane is in the transonic speed range. The function of the wing is to accelerate the air passing over its upper surface. The airflow may be subsonic at the leading edge of the wing but can be accelerated to become supersonic by the trailing edge of the wing, despite the fact that the airplane is flying at a speed of less than Mach 1.0. This is transonic flight, which usually occurs between Mach 0.75 and Mach 1.2. At speeds less than Mach 0.75 all the airflow over the wing is subsonic and as the airplane accelerates the first shockwave will form on the upper surface at the wing root. When the air over the upper surface of the wing becomes sonic, a shockwave forms because the pressure waves over the rear of wing at the wing root are attempting to move forward and meet the air moving aft from the leading edge at exactly the same speed but in the opposite direction. The meeting point is usually just aft of the point of maximum camber because this is where the air over the upper surface of the wing is accelerating at the greatest rate. The meeting point of the two air-pressure waves is the shockwave and is where the airflow changes from being sonic or supersonic to become subsonic. Air passing through the shockwave experiences an increase of pressure, temperature, and density. If the airplane speed continues to increase the area of supersonic air on top of the wing spreads backward towards the trailing edge, resulting in the shockwave moving aft.

learning.explanation: The formation and development of shock waves on the wing have effects on lift, drag, stability and control. Many of these effects are caused by shock induced separation. As the air flows through the shock wave, the sudden rise in pressure causes the boundary layer to thicken and often to separate. This increases the depth of the turbulent wake behind the wing. As an aircraft flies faster, the streamline pattern around the wing changes. Faster than about four tenths the speed of sound (M 0.4) these changes start to become significant. This phenomenon is known as compressibility. EFFECT OF SHOCK WAVES ON LIFT At low subsonic speeds the lift coefficient CL is assumed to be constant at a given angle of attack. With increasing Mach number, however, it will vary. At speeds above MCRIT a shock wave will have formed on the upper surface. This may cause boundary layer separation aft of the shock wave, causing loss of lift. Shock stall results from a separated boundary layer just as the low speed stall does. Shock stall occurs when the lift coefficient, as a function of Mach number, reaches its maximum value (for a given angle of attack). EFFECT OF SHOCK WAVES ON THE LIFT CURVE AND CLMAX At low speed, the streamline pattern is affected far ahead of the wing and the air has a certain distance in which to upwash. As speed increases, the wing gets closer to its leading pressure wave, and the streamline pattern is affected a shorter distance ahead so must approach the wing at a steeper angle. This change in the streamline pattern accentuates the adverse pressure gradient near the leading edge and flow separation occurs at a reduced angle of attack. Above M0.4, CLMAX decreases as seen in figure 1. At a constant angle of attack, the increase of CL as speed increases from about M 0.4 into the low end of the transonic region gives a steeper lift curve slope, i.e. the change of CL per degree angle of attack will increase, as seen in figure 2. Because of earlier separation resulting from the formation of the shock wave, CLMAX and the stalling angle will be reduced.

learning.explanation: A wing accelerates air over its upper surface, which, at high subsonic speeds, has the effect of causing that air to become supersonic (above Mach 1). The speed at which this first happens is known as MCRIT, above which speed, a shockwave will form on the upper section of the wing, usually near the wing root. At the lower critical Mach number, the airflow around the entire aircraft is subsonic. At the higher critical Mach number, the airflow around the whole aircraft is supersonic. Because of the critical Mach number, it is possible that shockwaves can occur at speeds even below Mach 1. As the aircraft speeds up beyond this critical Mach number, drag increases dramatically. If the aircraft is not designed for transonic or supersonic flight, this could lead to controllability problems. The critical Mach number increases with increasing wing sweepback. Thinner airfoils also increase the value of MCRIT. The critical Mach number decreases with increasing Angle of Attack. The drag divergence Mach number is the Mach number at which the aerodynamic drag on an airfoil begins to increase rapidly as the Mach number increases. The drag coefficient can multiply to 10 times its size compared to its low speed value. The drag divergence Mach number is a number bigger than Mcrit and smaller than Mach 1. The drag divergence Mach number can be increased by increasing wing sweepback.

learning.explanation: When an aircraft accelerates above approximately M0.4, the effects of compressibility begin to occur. The easiest way to understand this is by remembering that the aircraft produces pressure waves ahead of it (its wings in this context) which "tell the air that the wing is coming", so the air can begin to move out of the way. These pressure waves can only move at the speed of sound though, so as the aircraft itself starts going faster, the air gets less and less time to move away from the oncoming wing. This leads to a more aggressive uplift of air just ahead of the wing leading edge at high subsonic speeds, and this takes some energy out of the airflow (amongst some other effects). Together, these lead to a stall at lower angles of attack than usual. Therefore, when accelerating into the transonic regime, the wing's critical angle of attack (angle at which it stalls) reduces due to the compressibility effects ahead of the wing.

learning.explanation: One of the most used methods of increasing MCRIT is to sweep the wing back. This will provide better flight characteristics and lower drag in the transonic speed regime where large jets often operate. As it can be considered that compared to a straight wing, a swept-back wing of the same airfoil section has a smaller effective thickness chord ratio. Sweeping the wing back increases the effective aerodynamic chord for the same dimensional thickness, so the wing acts the same as a thinner wing. The other way to consider this relationship, is that the velocity of air flowing perpendicular to the wing span will be lower than the velocity of the freestream air. In this way, the MCRIT of an aeroplane with a swept wing will be higher and the transonic drag rise will be delayed. The air velocity perpendicular to the wing span corresponds to the free stream velocity multiplied by the cosine of the sweepback angle. This agrees with what we would expect as cos(0) = 1 and therefore the perpendicular airflow to the wing is the same as the freestream airflow when no sweep angle exists (i.e. an unswept wing) The sweepback angle is the angle between a straight wing (the aeroplane's lateral axis) and the 25% chord line of the swept wing. learning.explanation: As speed increases beyond the Critical Mach number (MCRIT), shock wave formation at the root of a swept-back wing will: reduce lift forward of the CG (CP moves rearward), and reduce downwash at the tail plane. Together, these factors will generate a nose-down pitching moment. At high Mach numbers, an aircraft will become unstable with respect to speed; instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further. A small increase in Mach number will give a nose-down pitch which will further increase the Mach number. This in turn leads to a further increase in the nose-down pitching moment. This unfavorable high-speed characteristic, known as “Mach Tuck”, “High Speed Tuck” or “Tuck Under” would restrict the maximum operating speed of a modern high-speed jet transport aircraft. To maintain the required stick force gradient at high Mach numbers, a Mach trim system must be fitted. It is operational at high Mach numbers in the transonic speed range. learning.explanation: Transonic flow is said to be the airflow where air flows above, at, and below the speed of sound at the same time at different points on an object. For example, the air on a wing flows faster, so that air could be supersonic while the air flowing over the body of an airplane could be subsonic. The transonic speed range is found at Mach 0.8-1.2. Severe instability can occur at transonic speeds. Shock waves can cause large-scale separation downstream, increasing drag and adding asymmetry and unsteadiness to the flow around the aircraft. When entering the transonic speed range, the Center of Pressure (CP) moves backward, causing a pitch down moment. learning.explanation: Critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the free stream Mach number (MFS ) at which the airflow over the upper surface of the wing becomes sonic (M=1), after which shockwaves will form. At speeds just above the Mcrit, only a tiny part of the wing is affected (wing root) and Coefficient of Lift (CL) continues to rise with EAS rise, until shock stall, as Also, if a straight and level flight is desired, then the angle of attack must be reduced. key_points: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i
e
wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT
learning.explanation: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i.e. wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT. It increases the cruise Mach number, the range, and the endurance of the airplane. The main features of a supercritical wing are: The upper surface is flattened but the lower surface is reflex cambered towards the trailing edge. Thus, the airflow over the upper surface is not accelerated as much as conventional airfoils, which delays the formation of the shockwave to a higher speed. Compared with a conventional airfoil section it has a larger leading-edge radius, a flatter upper surface and both positive and negative camber and enables a relatively thick wing to be used for approximately the same cruise Mach number. The curved lower surface increases the lift generated by the aft end of the airfoil and replaces some of the lift lost from the flat upper surface. Because of the rear-loaded lift generation it is often called an aft-loaded wing. The leading edge of the supercritical wing has a greater radius than traditional airfoils that suffer from excessive wave drag and the loss of longitudinal stability (tuck under). By ensuring that its profile is carefully designed any expansion waves will be reflected from the subsonic boundary back to the shockwave, thereby weakening its intensity.

learning.explanation: The critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the lower limit of a speed band, known as the transonic range, in which the local Mach number may be either subsonic or supersonic. Its value varies with the angle of attack and is the free-stream Mach number at which sonic speed is reached over the upper surface of a wing. In other words, it is the speed at which the local Mach number is equal to the free-airstream Mach number. It is also the highest speed possible without supersonic flow over the wing. The critical Mach number is inversely proportional to the angle of attack, i.e. MCRIT decreases with increasing angle of attack and vice versa. This is because, as the angle of attack increases the local peak velocity of the airflow over the wing also increases. It therefore reaches Mach 1 sooner than it would have done at a lower angle of attack; thus, the critical Mach number is less. A higher angle of attack decreases MCRIT and therefore, increases the shock wave intensity.

key_points: At the design stage of an aeroplane the name given to the principle adopted when matching parts of an aeroplane together so that they produce the minimum total drag is the ‘area rule’

The area rule states that provided the cross-sectional area of the aeroplane is similar to that of the ideal shape, the wave drag of the aeroplane will be similar to that of the ideal shape, irrespective of its actual shape
Wave drag is related to the curvature of the distribution of the volume of an aeroplane
learning.explanation: At the design stage of an aeroplane the name given to the principle adopted when matching parts of an aeroplane together so that they produce the minimum total drag is the ‘area rule’. The area rule states that provided the cross-sectional area of the aeroplane is similar to that of the ideal shape, the wave drag of the aeroplane will be similar to that of the ideal shape, irrespective of its actual shape. Wave drag is related to the curvature of the distribution of the volume of an aeroplane. The smoother the curvature the less is the magnitude of the wave drag. Large volumes of the airframe, such as the wings, are usually positioned at the widest part of the fuselage and other necessary features such as the cockpit, the tailplane and engine intakes have to be spread out along the fuselage to maintain the cross-sectional area distribution as near perfect as possible. For transonic aeroplanes it was discovered that indenting the fuselage to produce a waist and adding more volume to the rear of the aeroplane minimised transonic wave drag. Thus, the volume of the fuselage has to be decreased wherever a projection such as the wings and tailplane are positioned so that the cross-sectional area distribution changes smoothly with no discontinuities. This is sometimes referred to as the ‘coke bottle’ effect.

content.question: Compared with the low subsonic regime, in the high subsonic regime the streamlines ahead of the wing change direction...

options.A: further from the leading edge, resulting in a reduced Mach number for the high-speed stall.
options.B: at the same distance from the leading edge but are closer together above the wing due to compressibility.
options.C: closer to the leading edge, resulting in an increased indicated stall speed.

key_points: As an aircraft flies faster, the streamline pattern around the wing changes
Faster than about four tenths the speed of sound (M 0
4) these changes start to become significant
learning.explanation: As an aircraft flies faster, the streamline pattern around the wing changes. Faster than about four tenths the speed of sound (M 0.4) these changes start to become significant. This phenomenon is known as compressibility. Figure 1 shows that at low speed, the streamline pattern is affected far ahead of the wing and the air has a certain distance in which to upwash. As speed increases, the wing gets closer to its leading pressure wave, and the streamline pattern is affected a shorter distance ahead so must approach the wing at a steeper angle. This change in the streamline pattern accentuates the adverse pressure gradient near the leading edge and flow separation occurs at a reduced angle of attack. Above M0.4 CLMAX decreases as seen in figure 2. The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1/2ρV2. Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes. If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes. At a constant EAS, Mach number will increase as altitude increases. Figure 3 shows the variation of stalling speed with altitude at constant load factor (n). Such a curve is called the stalling boundary for the given load factor, in which altitude is plotted against equivalent airspeed. At this load factor (1g), the aircraft cannot fly at speeds to the left of this boundary. Over the lower range of altitude, stall speed does not vary with altitude. This is because at these low altitudes, the Mach number at VS is too low for compressibility effects to be present. Eventually (approximately 30000 ft), Mach number at VS has increased with altitude to such an extent that these effects are important, and the rise in stalling speed with altitude is apparent. As altitude increases, stall speed is initially constant then increases, due to compressibility.

key_points: In transonic flight it is the nature of the airflow behind a shock wave that determines the stability characteristics of the aircraft
Longitudinal stability is the most commonly affected form of stability
It is determined by movement of the centre of pressure, coupled with changes in the coefficient of lift and the amount of downwash acting on the tailplane
learning.explanation: In transonic flight it is the nature of the airflow behind a shock wave that determines the stability characteristics of the aircraft. Longitudinal stability is the most commonly affected form of stability. It is determined by movement of the centre of pressure, coupled with changes in the coefficient of lift and the amount of downwash acting on the tailplane. The nose-down pitching moment produced by the wing is counteracted by placing a small download on the tailplane. If the shock stall occurs, any lift aft of the shock wave is destroyed and the tailplane becomes covered in disturbed airflow. The downwash acting on the tailplane is consequently eliminated causing a smooth and radical change in its angle of attack. The angle of attack becomes more positive and the download acting on the tailplane becomes an upload which, in conjunction with the wing pitching moment, causes a violent nose-down pitching moment, known as tuck-under. The exact nature and strength of the changes in trim and stability depend on the design of the aircraft.

learning.explanation: 081.02.03.01.02: Explain how a change in alpha, aeroplane weight, manoeuvres, and centre-of-gravity (CG) position influences MCRIT. When air travels over an aerofoil in normal operation, the air above the aerofoil, near the leading edge, increases in velocity, due to the "squashing" of the streamlines together, causing a venturi effect, creating the low pressure zone that is required. This means that air is usually going faster over the top of the wing than anywhere else on the airframe. As the aircraft approaches the speed of sound, Mach 1, the air above the wing will get there first, as it is faster than the freestream airflow (TAS). In particular, it is usually the air just above the wing root, where the wing is thickest, and the streamlines get "squashed" the most, that is the first bit of air to reach the sound barrier. The TAS at which the first particle of air becomes sonic (exactly Mach 1) is called MCRIT, and is the beginning of the transonic speed regime. Above this speed, shockwaves will begin to form on various parts of the airframe. MCRIT is variable, and in particular depends on the airspeed increase over the wing. If the speed increase equates to M0.2, then the aircraft will have an MCRIT of M0.8, a higher MCRIT than if the speed increase due to the wing was M0.25, giving an MCRIT of M0.75. A higher MCRIT is better, as the drag increases rapidly just above the MCRIT, at MDD, the drag divergence speed, and we would like to fly as fast as possible with the lowest drag. The higher the angle of attack of the wing, the higher the speed increase, and therefore the lower the MCRIT. This would come from anything that increases the angle of attack, such as higher weight, or a more forward CG, which acts like increased weight due to the increased downforce from the tailplane. Effectively, bad things for performance such as increased weight or forward CG, cause a bad effect, lower MCRIT, due to increased AoA. Therefore, in this question, the more aft CG will cause a reduction in lift required by the main wing, which will require a lower angle of attack (lower lift coefficient for level flight), and the speed increase over the wing would be lower, so the aircraft can fly faster before getting shockwaves forming, thus a higher MCRIT, which is good.

This means that a greater proportion of the suction pressure will come from the rear of the wing and the centre of pressure is further aft. The aerodynamic centre moves back to the 50% chord position during transonic flight. As speed increases beyond MCRIT, shock wave formation will generate a nose-down pitching moment because there is less lift forward of the CG, and downwash on the tailplane is reduced. At high Mach numbers, an aircraft tends to become speed unstable. Instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further. When decelerating, the effect is reversed. The decreased shockwave formation will ease the nose-down pitch, and a decrease in speed will eventually require a nose-up trim.

key_points: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i
e
wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT
learning.explanation: A supercritical wing is one that has been designed with specific streamwise segments to delay the onset of the adverse effects of the shockwave, i.e. wave drag and its severity and decreased lateral stability, when the airplane is flying in the transonic speed range or just above MCRIT. It increases the cruise Mach number, the range, and the endurance of the airplane. The main features of a supercritical wing are: The upper surface is flattened but the lower surface is reflex cambered towards the trailing edge. Thus, the airflow over the upper surface is not accelerated as much as conventional airfoils, which delays the formation of the shockwave to a higher speed. Compared with a conventional airfoil section it has a larger leading-edge radius, a flatter upper surface and both positive and negative camber and enables a relatively thick wing to be used for approximately the same cruise Mach number. The curved lower surface increases the lift generated by the aft end of the airfoil and replaces some of the lift lost from the flat upper surface. Because of the rear-loaded lift generation it is often called an aft-loaded wing. The leading edge of the supercritical wing has a greater radius than traditional airfoils that suffer from excessive wave drag and the loss of longitudinal stability (tuck under). By ensuring that its profile is carefully designed any expansion waves will be reflected from the subsonic boundary back to the shockwave, thereby weakening its intensity.

learning.explanation: LOW SPEED VS. HIGH SPEED STREAMLINE (figure 1) As an aircraft flies faster, the streamline pattern around the wing changes. Faster than about four tenths the speed of sound (M 0.4) these changes start to become significant. This phenomenon is known as compressibility. At low speed, the streamline pattern is affected far ahead of the wing and the air has a certain distance in which to upwash. As speed increases, the wing gets closer to its leading pressure wave, and the streamline pattern is affected a shorter distance ahead so must approach the wing at a steeper angle. EFFECT OF MACH NUMBER ON CLMAX (figure2) This change in the streamline pattern accentuates the adverse pressure gradient near the leading edge and flow separation occurs at a reduced angle of attack. Above M0.4 CLMAX decreases. The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2 x W)/(ρ x S x CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1/2ρV2. Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes. If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes. STALLING SPEED vs. ALTITUDE (figure 3) At a constant EAS, Mach number increases as altitude increases. The variation of stalling speed with altitude at constant load factor (n). Such a curve is called the stalling boundary for the given load factor, in which altitude is plotted against equivalent airspeed. At this load factor (1g), the aircraft cannot fly at speeds to the left of this boundary. Over the lower range of altitude, stall speed does not vary with altitude. This is because at these low altitudes, the Mach number at VS is too low for compressibility effects to be present. Eventually (approximately 30000 ft), Mach number at VS has increased with altitude to such an extent that these effects are important, and the rise in stalling speed with altitude is apparent. As altitude increases, stall speed is initially constant then increases, due to compressibility.

learning.explanation: LOW SPEED VS. HIGH SPEED STREAMLINES (Figure 1) As an aircraft flies faster, the streamline pattern around the wing changes. Faster than about four tenths the speed of sound (M 0.4) these changes start to become significant. This phenomenon is known as compressibility. Coefficient of Lift (CL) is assumed to remain constant for a particular angle of attack at low subsonic speeds. In high subsonic speeds and the transonic speed regime, the compressibility of the air begins to take effect and, for a particular angle of attack, the coefficient of lift increases. This is because the air cannot "feel the wing coming" from as far away (due to it moving so fast), so has to react and get out of the way later. This is more aggressive and gains more lift from the air, but it also removes some of the energy from the air by doing this, and causes a much lower stalling angle of attack, and thereby decreases the CLMAX of the wing overall. This reduced stalling angle of attack is also what causes the low speed buffet boundary to get faster at high altitudes.

key_points: The terms compressibility and incompressibility describe the ability of molecules in a fluid to be compacted or compressed (made more dense) and their ability to bounce back to their original density, in other words, their "springiness
" An incompressible fluid cannot be compressed and has relatively constant density throughout
Liquid is an incompressible fluid
learning.explanation: The terms compressibility and incompressibility describe the ability of molecules in a fluid to be compacted or compressed (made more dense) and their ability to bounce back to their original density, in other words, their "springiness." An incompressible fluid cannot be compressed and has relatively constant density throughout. Liquid is an incompressible fluid. A gaseous fluid such as air, on the other hand, can be either compressible or incompressible. Generally, for theoretical and experimental purposes, gases are assumed to be incompressible when they are moving at low speeds (under approximately M0.4). The motion of the object traveling through the air at such speed does not affect the density of the air. This assumption has been useful in aerodynamics when studying the behavior of air in relation to airfoils and other objects moving through the air at slower speeds. However, when aircraft began traveling faster than M0.4, assumptions regarding the air through which they flew that were true at slower speeds were no longer valid. At high speeds some of the energy of the quickly moving aircraft goes into compressing the fluid (the air) and changing its density. The air at higher altitudes where these aircraft fly also has lower density than air nearer to the Earth's surface. The airflow is now compressible, and aerodynamic theories have had to reflect this.

learning.explanation: The critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the lower limit of a speed band, known as the transonic range, in which the local Mach number may be either subsonic or supersonic. Its value varies with the angle of attack and is the free-stream Mach number at which sonic speed is reached over the upper surface of a wing. In other words, it is the speed at which the local Mach number is equal to the free-airstream Mach number. It is also the highest speed possible without supersonic flow over the wing. The critical Mach number is inversely proportional to the angle of attack, i.e. MCRIT decreases with increasing angle of attack and vice versa. This is because, as the angle of attack increases the local peak velocity of the airflow over the wing also increases. It therefore reaches Mach 1 sooner than it would have done at a lower angle of attack; thus, the critical Mach number is less.

key_points: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag

learning.explanation: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag. This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft. The speed of sound is defined as the rate at which small pressure disturbances are propagated through the air, which is solely a function of air temperature. THE DEVELOPMENT OF SHOCK WAVES When aircraft fly through the air, every part of them sets up tiny pressure disturbances, which radiate outward at the speed of sound in all directions. As Mach number increases, the flow over the wing continues to accelerate and eventually reaches a sonic value at a particular point on the wing, normally the point of maximum thickness. With increasing Mach number, this point grows into an area of supersonic flow, so the air moving over the upper surface will be moving rearward faster than the pressure disturbances can move forward. These disturbances consequently pile up on each other and form a shock wave. The overall direction of the airflow remains the same, but as it passes through the shock wave, the following changes take place: - The flow is rapidly decelerated to a subsonic Mach number. - Static pressure increases. - Temperature increases. - Density increases. - The energy of the airstream (total pressure) is greatly reduced. In fluid dynamics, the pressure coefficient is a dimensionless number that describes the relative pressures throughout a flow. The increase in pressure due to the compressibility effects created by the presence of shockwaves will lead to an increase in the pressure coefficient.

learning.explanation: CRITICAL MACH NUMBER Critical Mach Number (MCRIT): The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft (usually the point of maximum thickness on the aerofoil) first reaches the speed of sound. An aerofoil generates lift by accelerating air over the top surface. At small angles of attack the highest local velocity on an aircraft will usually be located at the point of maximum thickness on the wing. At increased angles of attack the local velocity will be greater and further forward. Also, if the thickness/chord ratio were greater, the local speed will be higher. Increased thickness/chord ratio and increased angle of attack cause greater accelerations over the top surface of the wing, so the Critical Mach number will decrease with increasing thickness/chord ratio or angle of attack. If we consider two aeroplanes maintaining a constant flight level and flying at the same IAS, one heavier and one lighter, the heavier aeroplane will be flying at a greater AoA in order to maintain a constant flight level. As mentioned above, a higher AofA leads to a higher airflow acceleration over the upper wing surface for the heavier aeroplane, even though both are flying at the same speed. If both aeroplanes accelerate at the same rate, the heavier aeroplane would be the first to get into a situation where the airflow over the upper surface of its wings would locally reach a sonic speed. Therefore, at the same speed, the heavier aeroplane has a lower MCRIT due to the higher AoA. In conclusion: Higher mass = lower MCRIT due to a greater AoA to maintain a level flight at a given speed. Lower mass = higher MCRIT due to a smaller AoA to maintain a level flight at a given speed.

learning.explanation: A wing accelerates air over its upper surface, which, at high subsonic speeds, has the effect of causing that air to become supersonic (above Mach 1). The speed at which this first happens is known as MCRIT, above which speed, a shockwave will form on the upper section of the wing, usually near the wing root. In aircraft which are not designed for these high speeds, that can be dangerous, as the shockwave can cause airflow separation and loss of lift behind it. However, modern high speed jet aircraft are designed with this in mind, with swept back, supercritical wings, etc. These allow the aircraft to operate just above MCRIT, with a small penalty of increased drag, in return for extra speed. To reduce the severity of the shock stall and allow aircraft to travel faster, some modern jet transport category aircraft have supercritical wings.

content.question: Which of the following flight controls loses the most effectiveness after exceeding the MCRIT speed?

options.A: Spoilers
options.B: Ailerons
options.C: Rudder
options.D: Flaps

key_points: Exceeding the MCRIT speed means that the aircraft is in the transonic speed regime, and that the air going over the wing is becoming supersonic, and therefore forming a shockwave as it reduces back below supersonic speeds
The formation of the shockwave over the wing is the main focus of this question

Transonic effects do cause changes in elevator (pitch) controls due to Mach tuck, but the largest control surface change is the ailerons, as they are mounted on the main wings, and can interact quite badly with the shockwave formation
learning.explanation: Exceeding the MCRIT speed means that the aircraft is in the transonic speed regime, and that the air going over the wing is becoming supersonic, and therefore forming a shockwave as it reduces back below supersonic speeds. The formation of the shockwave over the wing is the main focus of this question. Transonic effects do cause changes in elevator (pitch) controls due to Mach tuck, but the largest control surface change is the ailerons, as they are mounted on the main wings, and can interact quite badly with the shockwave formation. When ailerons deflect downwards, they change the camber of the wing and cause further acceleration over the wing, which increases the magnitude of the shockwave. The shockwave causes shockwave induced separation behind it on the wing, and this greatly reduces the effect that ailerons can have, as they are trailing edge devices. The worst effect occurs when the section of the wing in front of the ailerons does not yet have a shockwave, so just above MCRIT, when the wing root has formed a shockwave but the thinner section near the wing tip has not. The down-going aileron can increase the camber enough to cause an isolated shockwave in that area, and this can massively reduce the lift from that section of the wing. Of course, that is the exact opposite of the desired effect, as that wing is supposed to be the one with more lift. Therefore, you get a aileron reversal effect, where you ask the aircraft to roll left but it actually rolls to the right. As for the other options: Spoilers are affected by shockwave formation, of course, but as they tend to accelerate the air over them, the shockwave would form right at the back of the spoiler, so they would have at least mostly the desired effect. The rudder is not massively affected by shockwave effects as the fin is very thin in comparison to the wing, and therefore doesn't accelerate the air as much, so shockwaves form much later, and quite evenly on either side of the fin. Flaps should not be used at transonic speeds, for so many reasons.

content.question: Immediately above MCRIT in the transonic speed regime, at a constant angle of attack, stall speed will...

options.A: decrease at high altitudes.
options.B: remain constant until reaching the lower end of the transonic speed regime.
options.C: remain constant until reaching the upper end of the transonic speed regime.
options.D: increase at high altitudes.

key_points: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1/2ρV2

Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes
If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes
learning.explanation: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1/2ρV2. Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes. If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes. At a constant EAS, Mach number will increase as altitude increases. Figure 1 shows the variation of stalling speed with altitude at constant load factor (n). Such a curve is called the stalling boundary for the given load factor, in which altitude is plotted against equivalent airspeed. At this load factor (1g), the aircraft cannot fly at speeds to the left of this boundary. Over the lower range of altitude, stall speed does not vary with altitude. This is because at these low altitudes, the Mach number at VS is too low for compressibility effects to be present. Eventually (approximately 30000 ft), Mach number at VS has increased with altitude to such an extent that these effects are important, and the rise in stalling speed with altitude is apparent. As altitude increases, stall speed is initially constant then increases, due to compressibility.

The magnitude of the pressure distribution (and MCRIT) is determined by the perpendicular component which, for a swept wing, is less than the free stream velocity

learning.explanation: For a swept wing, the free stream velocity is broken down to two components: a component which is perpendicular to the leading edge and a component parallel to the leading edge. The magnitude of the pressure distribution (and MCRIT) is determined by the perpendicular component which, for a swept wing, is less than the free stream velocity. Consequently, In transonic flight, a swept wing allows a higher Critical Mach Number (MCRIT) than a straight wing of similar chord and camber. This results in the principal advantage of wing sweep which is to delay the onset of wave drag.

key_points: As speed increases beyond the Critical Mach number (MCRIT), shock wave formation at the root of a swept-back wing will: reduce lift forward of the CG (CP moves rearward), and reduce downwash at the tail plane
Together, these factors will generate a nose-down pitching moment

At high Mach numbers, an aircraft will become unstable with respect to speed; instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further
learning.explanation: As speed increases beyond the Critical Mach number (MCRIT), shock wave formation at the root of a swept-back wing will: reduce lift forward of the CG (CP moves rearward), and reduce downwash at the tail plane. Together, these factors will generate a nose-down pitching moment. At high Mach numbers, an aircraft will become unstable with respect to speed; instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further. A small increase in Mach number will give a nose-down pitch which will further increase the Mach number. This in turn leads to a further increase in the nose-down pitching moment. This unfavorable high-speed characteristic, known as “Mach Tuck”, “High Speed Tuck” or “Tuck Under” would restrict the maximum operating speed of a modern high-speed jet transport aircraft. To maintain the required stick force gradient at high Mach numbers, a Mach trim system must be fitted.

key_points: Note: Recent feedback from Polish ULC indicates that the option containing "light buffet" is wrong, so we have changed the correct answer to that containing "severe buffet"

learning.explanation: Note: Recent feedback from Polish ULC indicates that the option containing "light buffet" is wrong, so we have changed the correct answer to that containing "severe buffet". We think that the "light buffet" is most correct, but this seems like the next best option for us, however we cannot be sure yet. Please let us know if you see this question in the exam, what the correct answer could have been (if you can find out) and which authority you sat the exam with, thank you! When an aircraft accelerates through the transonic speed range and exceeds its Critical Mach number, a normal shock wave can form on the upper surface of the wing. This shock wave induces flow separation, causing turbulent airflow over the wing and along the fuselage. This turbulent airflow can create airframe buffet, which is felt throughout the aircraft. If the tailplane is aligned with the separated airflow, the turbulent airflow caused by the flow separation can also hit the tail of the aircraft, which may result in a change in the aerodynamic forces acting on the tail and buffet. Option a) "up wash over the tail, causing a nose down pitching moment." is not correct because the flow separation on the wing does not cause upwash over the tail, but rather turbulent airflow and a slight reduction in downwash (naturally, due to the higher airspeed). There will be a nose-down pitching moment around this time, but it is due to the AC moving on the wing and the reduction in downwash, not upwash from the shockwave.

content.question: Behind a normal shock wave, the downwash is greatly reduced. As a consequence, this causes...

options.A: an increase in CL.
options.B: a reduction in CD.
options.C: an increase in critical AoA.
options.D: tuck under.

key_points: In transonic flight it is the nature of the airflow behind a shock wave that determines the stability characteristics of the aircraft
Longitudinal stability is the most commonly affected form of stability
It is determined by movement of the centre of pressure, coupled with changes in the coefficient of lift and the amount of downwash acting on the tailplane
learning.explanation: In transonic flight it is the nature of the airflow behind a shock wave that determines the stability characteristics of the aircraft. Longitudinal stability is the most commonly affected form of stability. It is determined by movement of the centre of pressure, coupled with changes in the coefficient of lift and the amount of downwash acting on the tailplane. The nose-down pitching moment produced by the wing is counteracted by placing a small download on the tailplane. If the shock stall occurs, any lift aft of the shock wave is destroyed and the tailplane becomes covered in disturbed airflow. The downwash acting on the tailplane is consequently eliminated causing a smooth and radical change in its angle of attack. The angle of attack becomes more positive and the download acting on the tailplane becomes an upload which, in conjunction with the wing pitching moment, causes a violent nose-down pitching moment, known as tuck-under. The exact nature and strength of the changes in trim and stability depend on the design of the aircraft.

content.question: Vortex generators mounted on the upper wing surface will:

options.A: decrease the interference drag of the trailing edge flaps.

key_points: The unfavorable characteristics associated with compressibility are due to boundary layer separation behind the shock wave (shock stall)
Flow separation occurs because the boundary layer loses kinetic energy as it flows against the adverse pressure gradient
Shock wave formation increases the adverse pressure gradient so the loss of kinetic energy in the boundary layer will be greater
learning.explanation: The unfavorable characteristics associated with compressibility are due to boundary layer separation behind the shock wave (shock stall). Flow separation occurs because the boundary layer loses kinetic energy as it flows against the adverse pressure gradient. Shock wave formation increases the adverse pressure gradient so the loss of kinetic energy in the boundary layer will be greater. Increasing the kinetic energy of the boundary layer will reduce flow separation. Simple devices called vortex generators are used to re-energize the boundary layer. Vortex generators are small plates, vanes, blades, or wedges mounted in spanwise rows along the wing surface. Each vortex generator produces a vortex at its tip which will induce high energy air from the free stream flow to mix with the boundary layer, thus increasing its kinetic energy and helping it flow through the shock wave with much less separation. Vortex generators are usually located on the upper wing surface, particularly ahead of control surfaces, but may be used anywhere where separation is causing high drag or reduced control effectiveness. It should be noted that vortex generators may also be used on subsonic aircraft to prevent separation caused by high adverse pressure gradients due to the contours of the surface.

key_points: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag
This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft

learning.explanation: During high-speed flight, significant changes occur in the flow and pressure distributions around the aircraft, which result in a loss of lift and an increase in drag. This is caused by the formation of shock waves, which adversely affect the stability and control characteristics of the aircraft. The speed of sound is defined as the rate at which small pressure disturbances are propagated through the air, which is solely a function of air temperature. THE DEVELOPMENT OF SHOCK WAVES When aircraft fly through the air, every part of them sets up tiny pressure disturbances, which radiate outward at the speed of sound in all directions. As Mach number increases, the flow over the wing continues to accelerate and eventually reaches a sonic value at a particular point on the wing, normally the point of maximum thickness. With increasing Mach number, this point grows into an area of supersonic flow, so the air moving over the upper surface will be moving rearward faster than the pressure disturbances can move forward. These disturbances consequently pile up on each other and form a shock wave. The shock wave acts perpendicular, or normal, to the surface, and is more commonly referred to as a normal shock wave. Notably, this occurs where the flow changes from supersonic back to subsonic.

content.question: As altitude increases, the stall speed (IAS):

options.A: remains constant until the tropopause but at higher altitudes increases.
options.B: initially remains constant but at higher altitudes increases.
options.C: remains constant regardless of altitude.
options.D: initially remains constant but at higher altitudes decreases.

key_points: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1/2 ρV2

Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes
If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes
learning.explanation: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1/2 ρV2. Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes. If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes. At a constant EAS, Mach number will increase as altitude increases. Figure 1 shows the variation of stalling speed with altitude at constant load factor (n). Such a curve is called the stalling boundary for the given load factor, in which altitude is plotted against equivalent airspeed. At this load factor (1g), the aircraft cannot fly at speeds to the left of this boundary. Over the lower range of altitude, stall speed does not vary with altitude. This is because at these low altitudes, the Mach number at VS is too low for compressibility effects to be present. Eventually (approximately 30000 ft), Mach number at VS has increased with altitude to such an extent that these effects are important, and the rise in stalling speed with altitude is apparent. As altitude increases, stall speed is initially constant then increases, due to compressibility.

key_points: As speed increases beyond the Critical Mach number (MCRIT), shock wave formation at the root of a swept-back wing will: reduce lift forward of the CG (CP moves rearward), and reduce downwash at the tail plane
Together, these factors will generate a nose-down pitching moment

learning.explanation: As speed increases beyond the Critical Mach number (MCRIT), shock wave formation at the root of a swept-back wing will: reduce lift forward of the CG (CP moves rearward), and reduce downwash at the tail plane. Together, these factors will generate a nose-down pitching moment. At high Mach numbers, an aircraft will become unstable with respect to speed; instead of an increasing push force being required as speed increases, a pull force becomes necessary to prevent the aircraft accelerating further. A small increase in Mach number will give a nose-down pitch which will further increase the Mach number. This in turn leads to a further increase in the nose-down pitching moment. This unfavorable high-speed characteristic, known as “Mach Tuck”, “High Speed Tuck” or “Tuck Under” would restrict the maximum operating speed of a modern high-speed jet transport aircraft. To maintain the required stick force gradient at high Mach numbers, a Mach trim system must be fitted. It is operational at high Mach numbers in the transonic speed range. In the event of this equipment failing, the speed is limited to specified Mach number.

content.question: An aerofoil with reduced camber compared to one with increased camber at high subsonic speed, at the same level and configuration will...

key_points: The critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the lower limit of a speed band, known as the transonic range, in which the local Mach number may be either subsonic or supersonic
Its value varies with the angle of attack and is the free-stream Mach number at which sonic speed is reached over the upper surface of a wing
In other words, it is the speed at which the local Mach number is equal to the free-airstream Mach number
learning.explanation: The critical Mach number (MCRIT) is the lower limit of a speed band, known as the transonic range, in which the local Mach number may be either subsonic or supersonic. Its value varies with the angle of attack and is the free-stream Mach number at which sonic speed is reached over the upper surface of a wing. In other words, it is the speed at which the local Mach number is equal to the free-airstream Mach number. It is also the highest speed possible without supersonic flow over the wing. The critical Mach number is inversely proportional to the angle of attack, i.e. MCRIT decreases with increasing angle of attack and vice versa. This is because, as the angle of attack increases the local peak velocity of the airflow over the wing also increases. It therefore reaches Mach 1 sooner than it would have done at a lower angle of attack; thus, the critical Mach number is less. At the design stage of an airplane the inclusion of some characteristics will increase the value of the critical Mach number: A thin airfoil cross-section (low thickness to chord ratio). Generally, a thicker wing with a large amount of camber has a lower critical Mach number than a thin wing with little camber because the airflow over its upper surface accelerates to a higher speed than it would over a thin wing. Therefore, an airfoil with reduced camber will have a higher MCRIT.
